questions.text: Sertoli cellss are seen in which of the following structure?
questions.solution:
Microscopic structure of the seminiferous tubules:

  • Seminiferous tubules are highly coiled tightly packed tubules present in the testis and each tubule measures about 50-80 cm in length and 150-250 μm in diameter.
  • These tubules are the sites where spermatozoa are produced by the process called spermatogenesis.
  • These tubules are lined with a specialised stratified germinal epithelium (seminiferous epithelium).
  • This epithelium consists of two distinct population of cells, the spermatogenic cells which are involved in spermatogenesis and the Sertoli cells which support and nourish the developing spermatozoa.
  • This specialised epithelium rests on a basement membrane beneath which lies some slender contract ile smooth muscle like cells called myoid cells.
  • Spermatogenic cells:
    • They are arranged in developmentally higher order from the basement membrane to the lumen.
    • Namely spermatogonia, spermatocytes, spermatids and spermatozoa.
  • Sertoli cells:
    • They are basically tall columnar cells which extend from basement membrane to lumen of seminiferous tubule.
    • They exhibit many cytoplasmic processes which surround all spermatogenic cells.
    • They have distinct oval nuclei with well developed nucleoli. This feature distinguishes them from other spermatogenic cells.

Key Points:

questions.text: Which of the following methods is the most sensitive for diagnosing Trichomonas vaginalis infection, and it can detect trophozoites directly in vaginal secretion?
questions.solution:
• (A) Wet saline mount: Wet mount examination can demonstrate jerky motility of the trophozoites and is a commonly used method for diagnosing Trichomonas vaginalis. However, its sensitivity is variable (40-80%) compared to other methods.
  • (B) Microscopic agglutination test (MAT): MAT is primarily used to diagnose leptospirosis and not specifically for Trichomonas vaginalis.
  • (C) Direct fluorescent antibody test (DFA): This method is more sensitive (70-90%) than wet mount examination and is highly specific for Trichomonas vaginalis, as it uses monoclonal antibodies to detect the pathogen directly.
  • (D) Giemsa stain: Giemsa stain can be used to visualize trophozoites but is not as sensitive or widely used as DFA for diagnosing Trichomonas vaginalis.

Key Takeaways:

  • DFA is highly sensitive and specific for detecting Trichomonas vaginalis.
  • Wet mount can be used but has a lower sensitivity (40-80%).
  • DFA uses monoclonal antibodies and gives a clearer, more reliable diagnosis compared to other methods.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man with no previous illnesses has been bothered by progressive hoarseness, shortness of breath, and stridor for the past 3 weeks. On physical examination, he has a firm, large, tender mass involving the entire right thyroid lobe. CT scan shows extension of this mass posterior to the trachea and into the upper mediastinum. A fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the mass is done, and microscopically shows pleomorphic spindle cells. The mass is noted at surgery to have infiltrated the adjacent skeletal muscle. Four of seven cervical lymph nodes have metastases. Pulmonary metastases also are identified on a chest radiograph. Which of the following neoplasms is most likely to be present in this man?
questions.solution:
A) The clinical presentation and histological findings are consistent with anaplastic carcinoma of the thyroid gland.

  • Anaplastic carcinoma is a rare and aggressive type of thyroid cancer that typically presents with a rapidly growing, firm, and tender mass in the thyroid gland.
  • The tumor often extends beyond the thyroid gland and invades adjacent structures, such as the trachea, esophagus, and skeletal muscle.
  • The histological findings of pleomorphic spindle cells, which are characteristic of anaplastic carcinoma, are consistent with this diagnosis.
  • Additionally, the presence of lymph node metastases and pulmonary metastases further supports the diagnosis of anaplastic carcinoma.

B) Follicular carcinoma typically presents with a more slowly growing, encapsulated mass, and the histological findings are typically characterized by follicular architecture and capsular or vascular invasion.

C) Medullary carcinoma typically presents with a more slowly growing, firm mass, and the histological findings are typically characterized by spindle-shaped cells and amyloid deposition.

D) Non-Hodgkin lymphoma of the thyroid gland is a rare condition that typically presents with a rapidly growing mass, but the histological findings are typically characterized by a lymphoid infiltrate, rather than pleomorphic spindle cells.

Key takeaways:

Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma: sarcomatoid(Malignant spindle cell) architecture and central zone of necrosis.

Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma: pleomorphic tumor cells infiltrating skeletal muscle bundles

questions.text: Which of the following mutations is most commonly associated with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 2 (MEN 2)?
questions.solution:
A) The RET gene mutations associated with MEN 2 typically lead to the activation of the RET protein, resulting in uncontrolled cell growth and tumor formation.

B) The MEN1 gene is associated with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 1 (MEN 1), a different genetic disorder.

C) The VHL gene is associated with Von Hippel-Lindau disease, a genetic disorder that predisposes to the development of certain types of tumors.

D) The TP53 gene is a tumor suppressor gene that is associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome, a genetic disorder that predisposes to the development of certain types of cancer.

Key takeaways:

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 2 (MEN 2) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the development of tumors in multiple endocrine glands, including the thyroid, adrenal, and parathyroid glands.

The RET proto-oncogene is a gene that encodes a receptor tyrosine kinase involved in cell signaling pathways. Mutations in the RET gene are the primary cause of MEN 2, and are found in the majority of cases.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true about Japanese Encephalitis?
questions.solution:
• (A) Humans are reservoir hosts: This statement is incorrect. Humans are incidental hosts for Japanese Encephalitis (JE). The primary reservoir hosts are water birds and pigs, not humans. Humans can be infected but do not harbor the virus long-term or contribute to its transmission.
  • (B) Pigs are amplifier hosts: This statement is true. Pigs can become infected with JE virus and develop high levels of the virus in their bloodstream, acting as amplifiers of the virus and increasing the risk of transmission to mosquitoes that bite them.
  • (C) Transmitted by Culex vishnui: This is correct. Culex mosquitoes, particularly Culex vishnui, are the primary vectors responsible for transmitting the Japanese Encephalitis virus in endemic areas.
  • (D) Vaccination of pigs controls transmission: This is true. Vaccinating pigs can help control the transmission of JE by reducing the viral load in pigs and, consequently, reducing the number of infectious mosquitoes.

Key Takeaways:

  • Japanese Encephalitis is primarily transmitted by Culex mosquitoes and involves pigs as amplifier hosts, not reservoir hosts.
  • Vaccination of pigs can significantly help in controlling transmission.
  • Humans are incidental hosts, not the primary reservoir of the virus.

questions.text: Cori cycle is related with
questions.solution:
Glucose is formed from two groups of compounds that undergoes Gluconeogenesis.

  1. Direct net conversion to glucose including Amino Acid & Propionate
  2. Product of the metabolism of glucose in tissues - Lactate Formed in glycolysis in skeletal muscle and RBC is transported to liver and kidney for Gluconeogenesis. This process is known as the Cori Cycle or the Lactic Acid Cycle.

Option C) Glucose Alanine Cycle - In fasting state there is a considerable output of alanine from skeletal muscle, far in excess of the amount in the muscle proteins that are being catabolized.

Transamination of pyruvate produced by glycolysis of muscle glycogen and is exported to the liver where, after transamination back to pyruvate , it is a substrate for gluconeogenesis. Glucose Alanine cycle provides indirect way of utilizing muscle glycogen to maintain blood glucose in the fasting state.

questions.text: A 47 year old man recently diagnosed with exertional angina started treatment with sublingual nitroglycerin, as needed and oral isosorbide mononitrate. Which of the following is a potential detrimental effect of nitrates in the prophylactic treatment of exertional angina?
questions.solution:
• By causing peripheral vasodilation, high doses of nitrates can induce reflex tachycardia, which in turn increases oxygen consumption.
  • This detrimental effect can be prevented by the concomitant use of a β-blocker.
  • Different nitrates
    • Glyceryl Trinitrate / Nitroglycerine [GTN/ NTG]
    • Isosorbide Dinitrate [IDN]
    • Isosorbide Mononitrate [IMN]
    • Penta Erythrital Tetra Nitrate [PETN]
    • Amyl Nitrite [AN]
  • Nitrates should not be given with Sildenafil [Risk of Severe hypotension]
  • Adverse effects These are mostly due to vasodilatation.
  • Mnemonic [MRF]
    • Methemoglobinemia
    • Rashes are rare (common with pentaerythritol tetranitrate)
    • Fullness in head, throbbing headache;
    • Flushing, weakness, sweating, palpitation, dizziness and fainting; these are due to postural hypotension

Option A & C: These are all useful effects of nitrates in exertional angina.

Option D: Nitrates tend to decrease, not increase, ventricular enddiastolic volume.

Key takeaway

  • Nitrates can cause reflex tachycardia and reflex increase in cardiac contractility, but these are detrimental, not therapeutic, effects in patients with angina.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old female has Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Myocardial biopsy showing lipofuscin accumulation in cardiomyocytes
What is the underlying mechanism?
questions.solution:
Oxidative stress and lipid peroxidation:

  • Lipofuscin accumulation in cardiomyocytes is a hallmark of oxidative stress.
  • Lipid peroxidation results in the formation of reactive aldehydes, which cross-link proteins and lipids, forming lipofuscin.
  • Oxidative stress contributes to cellular damage and dysfunction in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

Appears as yellow-brown, finely granular intracytoplasmic, often perinuclear pigment.

Lipofuscin accumulation in the heart muscle as process of ageing is called "Brown atrophy of heart"

  • This mechanism is supported by studies showing increased oxidative stress markers in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

Option A: Mitochondrial dysfunction and ATP depletion:

  • Mitochondrial dysfunction can contribute to cardiomyopathy.
  • ATP depletion can lead to cellular damage and dysfunction.
  • Mitochondrial dysfunction may contribute to oxidative stress, but it's not the primary mechanism for lipofuscin formation.

Option C: Inflammatory response and cytokine release:

  • Inflammation plays a role in cardiomyopathy pathogenesis.
  • Cytokine release contributes to inflammation and tissue damage.
  • Inflammation may contribute to oxidative stress, but it's not the primary mechanism for lipofuscin formation.

Option D: Genetic mutation and telomere shortening:

  • Genetic mutations can contribute to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy susceptibility.
  • Telomere shortening is associated with aging and cellular senescence.
  • Genetic mutations may contribute to mitochondrial dysfunction or oxidative stress, but it's not the primary mechanism for lipofuscin formation.

questions.text: A premature infant who has hypoxia was given 100% oxygen for few days. Later, it was noted that patient has serious visual defect. Infant was diagnosed with retrolental fibroplasia on thorough evaluation. Not true about it is
questions.solution:
• Option a: The retinal receptors mature from the center to the periphery of the retina, and they use considerable O2. This causes the retina to become vascularized in an orderly manner. Oxygen treatment before maturation is complete provides the needed O2 to the photoreceptors, and consequently the normal vascular pattern fails to develop instead it is more vascularized..
  • Option b: Evidence indicates that this condition can be prevented or ameliorated by treatment with vitamin E, which exerts an anti-oxidant effect.
  • Option c: Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) is the clinical condition associated with retrolental fibroplasia. It is primarily seen in premature infants exposed to prolonged supplemental oxygen therapy, which disrupts the normal development of retinal blood vessels.
  • Option d: Since option b is not true, d is not the correct answer.

choices.text: Epithelial lining of the respiratory tract
Epithelial lining of the oral cavity
Epithelial lining of the urinary tract
Epithelial linig of the middle ear cavity

questions.text: All of the followings structures are derivative of the endoderm, except?
questions.solution:
The endoderm gives rise to:

  • Epithelial lining of the respiratory tract (e.g., trachea, bronchi, lungs)
  • Epithelial lining of the urinary tract (specifically the bladder and urethra, except for parts derived from the cloaca)
  • Epithelial lining of the middle ear cavity and Eustachian tube

However, the epithelial lining of the oral cavity is derived from the ectoderm, not the endoderm.

Formation of germ disc:

  • All the three primary germ layers are derived from epiblast.
  • The cells of embryoblast differentiate and arrange themselves into two layers:
    • A superficial layer of columnar cells called the epiblast
    • A deep layer of flattened cells called the hypoblast. (Thus, embryoblast becomes a bilaminar germ disc.)
  • The cells of epiblast migrate towards the primitive streak. As they reach in the region of the primitive streak, they become flask shaped, detach themselves from the epiblast, and slip beneath it.
  • The flask-shaped cells of epiblast move inward (invaginate) towards the hypoblast. Some of these cells replace the hypoblast cells to form the endoderm and others come to lie between the epiblast and the newly formed endoderm to form the mesoderm.
  • The remaining cells of the epiblast now form the ectoderm.

Derivatives of three germ layers:

Key Points:

Derivatives of the endoderm:

  • Epithelial lining of
    • Gastrointestinal tract
    • Respiratory tract
    • Urinary tract
    • Biliary tract
    • Auditory tube and middle ear cavity
    • Uterus and upper part of vagina
  • Liver (hepatocytes)
  • Pancreas (acinar and islet)
  • Thuroid follicles
  • Parathyroid (principle and oxyphil cells)

questions.text: Which virus is responsible for causing Exanthem subitum or Roseola infantum?
questions.solution:
Human Herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) causes Exanthem subitum or Roseola infantum, which is characterized by high fever followed by a rash. It primarily affects infants and young children.

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Roseola Infantum (Exanthem Subitum):
    • Symptoms: Characterized by a sudden high fever lasting 3-5 days, followed by a rash once the fever resolves. The rash typically starts on the trunk and spreads to the neck, arms, and legs.
    • Affected Population: Primarily affects infants and young children, usually between 6 months and 2 years of age.
  • Other Associations: HHV-6 has also been linked to various other conditions, including:
    • Post-Transplant Complications: Can cause complications in transplant patients due to its effect on the immune system.
    • Neurological Disorders: HHV-6A has been implicated in some neurological conditions, although this link is less clearly defined.

Transmission:

  • Route: HHV-6 is primarily transmitted through respiratory secretions. It may also spread through direct contact with infected individuals.

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical Diagnosis: Based on the characteristic presentation of high fever followed by rash.
  • Laboratory Testing:
    • PCR Testing: Detects HHV-6 DNA in blood or tissues.
    • Serology: Identifies antibodies against HHV-6, although PCR is more commonly used for diagnosis.

Treatment:

  • Roseola Infantum: Generally, treatment is supportive and includes managing fever with antipyretics and ensuring adequate hydration.
  • Severe Cases: In cases with complications or severe manifestations, antiviral medications such as ganciclovir may be used, but this is not common for typical roseola.

Prevention:

  • Hygiene Practices: Good hygiene, including hand washing and avoiding close contact with infected individuals, can help reduce the risk of transmission.

Incorrect options:

  • Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV): VZV causes chickenpox (varicella) and shingles (herpes zoster).
  • Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV): HSV causes conditions like cold sores (HSV-1) or genital herpes (HSV-2).
  • Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV): EBV is the causative agent of infectious mononucleosis. The characteristic signs of EBV infection include fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes, but it does not cause Roseola. The rash in EBV is different and not the typical roseola rash

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). (2024). Roseola. Retrieved from CDC Roseola

questions.text: A 36-year-old man complained to his physician of dizziness and drowsiness. The man, recently diagnosed with gastroesophageal reflux disease, had started an appropriate treatment 2 weeks earlier. Laboratory findings showed an increase of the patient's prolactin levels. Which of the following drugs could have caused the signs and symptoms of this patient?
questions.solution:
• Metoclopramide is an antagonist of D2 and 5-HT3 receptors.
  • Blockade of D2 receptors in the central nervous system can cause dizziness and drowsiness
  • Blockade of D2 receptors in the pituitary leads to hyperprolactinemia, a common adverse effect of metoclopramide
  • Side effects of Metoclopramide:
    • Sedation,
    • Dizziness,
    • Loose stools,
    • Muscle dystonias (especially in children)

Long-term use can cause parkinsonism, galactorrhoea and gynaecomastia

Option A, B & C: All of these do not block D2 receptors hence they do not lead to typical side effects of Metoclopramide

Key Takeaway

  • Blockade of D2 receptors in the pituitary by metoclopramide leads to hyperprolactinemia in short term.
  • It can also cause parkinsonism, galactorrhoea and gynaecomastia in long term

questions.text: Inhaling the cloth soaked in drug is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Huffing:

  • Huffing refers to the act of inhaling volatile substances or drugs by saturating a cloth or other material and then inhaling the fumes.
  • Huffing is a form of inhalant abuse, and it can have harmful effects on the body, including intoxication and potential damage to the respiratory system.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Bagging: Bagging refers to a method of inhaling substances by placing them inside a bag and then inhaling or breathing in the vapors. The bag is typically held over the nose and mouth, allowing the person to inhale the substance contained within the bag.
  • Option B - Spraying: Spraying typically involves the dispersal of liquid substances in a fine mist or spray form.
  • Option D - Sniffing: Sniffing refers to the act of inhaling substances directly through the nose.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Huffing refers to the act of inhaling volatile substances or drugs by saturating a cloth or other material and then inhaling the fumes

questions.text: Which of the following is commonly used as the anesthetic solution in a peribulbar block?
questions.solution:
Peribulbar blocks are commonly used for intraocular anesthesia and analgesia, and have largely replaced retrobulbar blocks due to lower risks of optic nerve damage. However, they provide less akinesia compared to retrobulbar blocks. The procedure involves two injections, with a risk of vascular damage.

Procedure:

  1. Anesthetic mixture:
    • 5 ml Bupivacaine 0.75%
    • 5 ml Lignocaine 2% with 1:200,000 adrenaline
    • 75 units of Hyaluronidase (Bupivacaine gives prolonged efficacy, lignocaine ensures faster onset, and hyaluronidase aids diffusion.)
  2. Needle: 25 gauge, 2.5 cm disposable needle.
  3. Positioning: Patient lies supine, looking straight ahead.
  4. First Injection: Transconjunctival or transcutaneous approach at the junction of the middle two-thirds and lateral one-third of the lower lid (about 2.5 cm in depth). Inject 5 ml of the mixture into the lateral adipose tissue.
  5. Second Injection: Just medial to the middle canthus, inject 3 ml at 2.5 cm depth.
  6. Pressure: Apply pressure to both injection sites for a couple of minutes.
  7. Optional: Honan pressure cuff applied for 15 minutes.

Time to Effect: Anaesthesia starts in 5 minutes, but full effect takes about 15 minutes.

Uses: Common in cataract, glaucoma, keratoplasty, vitreoretinal, and strabismus surgeries. Supplemental injections may be required for persistent movement in the inferior or superior gaze.

questions.text: Which of the following is a common ocular side effect of chloroquine use?
questions.solution:
Chloroquine and Ocular Toxicity

  • Uses: Antimalarial drug, also used for SLE, discoid lupus, and rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Ocular Side Effects:
    • Keratopathy: Affects the cornea.
    • Retinopathy: Pigmentary degeneration, leading to visual field defects (e.g., central scotoma) and bull's-eye maculopathy.
    • Optic neuropathy: Rarely directly related, usually a consequence of retinopathy.
    • Visual Field Changes: Fluorescein angiography reveals pigment disturbance and retinal atrophy with clumping.
    • Other symptoms: Blurred vision, diplopia, keratopathy, pigmentary retinopathy, optic atrophy.
  • Dosage:
    • Toxicity Risk: Occurs primarily with high or prolonged doses.
    • Maximum daily dose: 6 mg/kg for chloroquine, 5 mg/kg for hydroxychloroquine.
    • Hydroxychloroquine has lower ocular toxicity but weaker anti-inflammatory effects.
  • Early Detection:
    • Perimetry: Static perimetry to detect retinal toxicity.
    • Amsler grid: Self-monitoring at home for early signs of vision distortion (metamorphopsia).
    • Color vision tests: Helpful in monitoring early toxicity.
  • Reversibility:
    • Short-term effects (blurring, diplopia) are reversible upon discontinuing the drug.
    • Long-term effects (keratopathy) are also reversible if caught early.
    • Retinopathy and optic atrophy may be irreversible if detected late.

questions.text: In hypersensitivity type 1, which of the following chemokines play a role in the recruitment of eosinophils to the site of reaction?
questions.solution:
Eotaxin plays a role in the recruitment of eosinophils to the site of reaction

In late phase reaction of type 1 HSR, leukocytes are recruited that amplify and sustain the inflammatory response without additional exposure to triggering antigen.

Eosinophis are often abundant leukocyte population in these reactions which are recruited to sites of immediate hypersensitivity by chemokines, such as EOTAXIN and others.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Fractalkine - Specific for monocyte.

Option C: IL - 8 - Specific for neutrophils.

Option D: MCP -1 - Specific for monocyte.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Eotaxin plays a role in the recruitment of eosinophils to the site of reaction

choices.text: Paragonimus westermani; stool examination for eggs
Paragonimus westermani; sputum examination for eggs
Ascaris lumbricoides; stool examination for larvae

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of progressive cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis. He recently returned from a hiking trip in Southeast Asia, where he consumed local delicacies including raw freshwater crustaceans. Chest X-ray shows bilateral infiltrates, and a sputum sample reveals eggs with opercula. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the best diagnostic method to confirm the presence of the parasite?
questions.solution:
• A) Paragonimus westermani; stool examination for eggs: While stool examination can sometimes detect Paragonimus eggs, sputum is more commonly used to identify the eggs in patients with respiratory symptoms, such as hemoptysis and cough.
  • B) Paragonimus westermani; sputum examination for eggs: This is the most appropriate diagnostic approach. The eggs of westermani can be found in sputum samples, and their presence in respiratory secretions confirms the diagnosis. Chest X-rays often show characteristic infiltrates.
  • C) Schistosoma japonicum; serology for antibodies: Schistosoma japonicum is a different parasitic infection that causes liver and gastrointestinal symptoms, not respiratory symptoms. Serology can be useful for diagnosing schistosomiasis, but it is not appropriate for diagnosing Paragonimus.
  • D) Ascaris lumbricoides; stool examination for larvae: Ascaris infection typically involves the gastrointestinal tract, and eggs, not larvae, are the usual findings in stool. This option is unrelated to the clinical presentation of Paragonimus.

Key Takeaways:

  • Paragonimus westermani is a lung fluke commonly found in Southeast Asia and transmitted by ingesting undercooked freshwater crustaceans.
  • Diagnosis is best confirmed by sputum examination for the characteristic eggs with operculum.
  • Chest X-ray can show bilateral infiltrates, which is common in paragonimiasis.

Important Points:

  • The clinical symptoms include persistent cough, hemoptysis, chest pain, and occasionally fever.
  • The eggs have a distinctive operculum that can be seen under microscopy in sputum samples.
  • Treatment involves praziquantel, an anthelmintic drug effective against flukes.

References:

  • Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Paragonimus westermani - Lung Fluke Infection. CDC Guidelines
  • World Health Organization (WHO). Parasitic Diseases.

choices.text: To speed up the maturation of the lungs
To close the patent ductus arteriosus

questions.text: An 850-gm baby boy, prematurely born at 27 week's gestational age, was intubated immediately and placed on positive pressure assisted ventilation. On the third day of life, his nurse noticed that he had tachycardia and a widened pulse pressure. Color Doppler echocardiography showed reverse pulmonary artery flow in diastole. A treatment with intravenous indomethacin was started. Which of the following best explains the reason for that therapy?
questions.solution:
• The patient's symptoms and the echocardiography results suggest he had a patent ductus arteriosus, which can occur in up to 80% of premature infants with a birth weight less than 1200 gm.
  • Patency of the ductus arteriosus is maintained in utero by the low partial pressure of oxygen and high concentration of prostaglandins, mainly PGE1 and PGE2, which have vasodilatory actions.
  • Because of this, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs have been found to speed up the closure of the ductus arteriosus in newborn babies.
  • Indomethacin given intravenously is the treatment of choice and can achieve closure in more than 70% of neonates.

Uses of Indomethacin:

  • Because of prominent adverse effects, indomethacin is used as a reserve drug in conditions requiring potent anti-inflammatory action like
    • Ankylosing spondylitis,
    • Acute exacerbations of destructive arthropathies,
    • Psoriatic arthritis
    • Acute gout or rheumatoid arthritis that are not responding to better tolerated NSAIDs.
  • Malignancy associated fever refractory to other antipyretics may respond to indomethacin.
  • It has been the most common drug used for medical closure of patent ductus arteriosus: three 12 hourly i.v. injections of 0.1-0.2 mg/kg achieve closure in majority of cases.
  • Bartter's syndrome responds dramatically, as it does to other PG synthesis inhibitors.

Key takeaway

  • Indomethacin given intravenously is the treatment of choice and can achieve closure in more than 70% of neonates.

questions.text: A 53 year old woman recently diagnosed with ovarian cancer started her first cycle of combination chemotherapy with paclitaxel, cisplatin, and cyclophosphamide. Which of the following most specific drug should also be administered to counteract a specific adverse effect of cyclophosphamide?
questions.solution:
• Cyclophosphamide can cause hemorrhagic cystitis, which seems to be due mainly to acrolein, an active metabolite that is excreted in high concentration in the urine.
  • Prevention consists of providing adequate intravenous hydration and administration of 2-mercaptoethane sulfonate (MESNA).
  • This agent contains a free thiol group that can neutralize acrolein in the bladder.
  • MESNA can prevent the bladder toxicity completely, so its use is the current standard of care.
  • Cyclophosphamide is a prodrug and is activated by hepatic biotransformation to aldophosphamide.
  • One of its degradation products is acrolein that is responsible for hemorrhagic cystitis (its characteristic adverse effect).
  • This adverse effect can be decreased by vigorous hydration and by the use of mercapto ethane sulfonic acid (mesna).
  • To protect the bladder, MESNA, a -SH compound is mostly given with it.
  • Mesna is excreted in urine-binds and inactivates the vasicotoxic metabolites of ifosfamide and cyclophosphamide.

Option A, B & D: None of these drugs can prevent cyclophosphamide induced hemorrhagic cystitis.

Key takeaway

  • Cyclophosphamide can cause hemorrhagic cystitis, which seems to be due mainly to acrolein, an active metabolite that is excreted in high concentration in the urine.
  • Prevention consists of providing adequate intravenous hydration and administration of 2-mercaptoethane sulfonate (MESNA).

choices.text: Fuller's earth is given as treatment
Hemodialysis is useful if done within 12 hours of ingestion

questions.text: An elderly farmer is brought to the casualty by his son with cough, hemoptysis, and dyspnea after alleged ingestion of Paraquat from his field. Which among the following is false about its overdose?
questions.solution:
Gastric lavage may be beneficial if done within one hour of exposure.

Paraquat is a bipyridylium compound and used as herbicide and weed-killer. It undergoes a NADPH dependent reduction to form the free radical.

Absorption is mainly through the GI tract. It is present in highest concentrations in the kidneys and the lungs, followed by muscles. Early feature of bone marrow toxicity is polymorphonuclear leucocytosis. Anemia is a late feature in paraquat poisoning.

Treatment:

  • Gastric lavage may be beneficial if done within one hour of exposure.
  • Emetics are contraindicated.
  • Fuller's earth is given as a treatment.
  • Haemodialysis and hemoperfusion is useful if done within 12 hours of ingestion.
  • Avoid oxygen therapy.

questions.text: A patient with a bile duct obstruction develops necrosis of bile duct cells. Which intracellular protein is likely to be elevated in their serum?
questions.solution:
Mechanism:

  1. Bile Duct Obstruction: When the bile ducts are blocked (e.g., by gallstones, tumors, or strictures), bile cannot flow out of the liver properly.
  2. ALP Production: ALP is an enzyme primarily produced by the cells lining the bile ducts. In response to obstruction, these cells increase ALP production.
  3. Leakage into Blood: As bile accumulates, ALP is released into the bloodstream, leading to elevated serum levels.

Explanation:

  1. Necrosis of bile duct cells leads to leakage of ALP into the bloodstream.
  2. Troponin is elevated in cardiac conditions.
  3. LDH is a non-specific enzyme that can be elevated in various conditions.
  4. AST is more specific to liver or cardiac damage.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Necrosis of bile duct cells leads to leakage of ALP into the bloodstream

questions.text:
Identify the correct order of below mention Enzymes of Electron Transport Chain starting from NADH.
1. ATP Synthase
2. Cytochrome C Oxidoreductase
3. Cytochrome C Oxidase
4. NADH Dehydrogenase
questions.solution:
Pathway that an electron takes in the Electron Transport Chain (ETC) starting from NADH, the order of complexes and carriers involved is as follows:

  1. NADH Dehydrogenase (Complex I) - NADH donates electrons to Complex I.
  2. Cytochrome C Oxidoreductase (Complex III) - Electrons are passed from ubiquinone (after Complex I) to Complex III.
  3. Cytochrome C - Electrons are transferred from Complex III to the soluble carrier protein Cytochrome C.
  4. Cytochrome C Oxidase (Complex IV) - Electrons are transferred from Cytochrome C to Complex IV, where they are used to reduce oxygen to water.
  5. ATP Synthase (Complex V) - Protons that were pumped across the membrane during electron transport flow back through ATP Synthase, generating ATP.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was diagnosed with cerebral palsy. Child has abnormal rapid involuntary movement of distal part of the limbs. Which type of cerebral palsy this patient has?
questions.solution:
• Cerebral palsy is a nonprogressive neurological disorder occurring during or before child birth or in early childhood.
  • It is of three types
  • Option b: It is Characterized by involuntary, abnormal movements, including rapid, jerky (choreiform) or slow, writhing (athetotic) motions. These movements typically involve the distal limbs and can worsen with stress or voluntary actions. It results from basal ganglia damage, which matches this child's symptoms.
  • Option a: It is most common type of cerebral palsy, characterized by increased muscle tone (spasticity), leading to stiff and jerky movements. Primarily affects the upper motor neurons, causing difficulty in movement and posture. It does not present with involuntary, rapid movements as seen in this case.
  • Option c: The rarest type is hypotonic CP that presents with truncal and extremity hypotonia, hyperreflexia, and persistent primitive reflexes.
  • Option d: It is Incorrect option, as the child’s symptoms align with dyskinetic cerebral palsy, which includes involuntary rapid movements of the distal limbs.

choices.text: Gene for CFTR is located on chromosome no. 7
Conductance of Cl- channel is altered in cystic fibrosis
Functioning of mucociliary escalator is impaired

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is suffering from chronic cough. On visit to pediatrician boy was diagnosed with genetic disorder cystic fibrosis by genetic screening. True about cystic fibrosis is
questions.solution:
• Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator) gene.
  • Option a: The CFTR gene, which encodes a protein that functions as a chloride channel, is located on the long arm of chromosome 7. 5 types of mutations are seen in cystic fibrosis. Type 2 is most common that limits the amount of CFTR protein that gets to the plasma membrane.
  • Option b: The CFTR protein is responsible for chloride (Cl-) ion transport across epithelial cells in various organs, including the lungs, pancreas, and sweat glands.

In CF, mutations in the CFTR gene result in defective or absent chloride channels, which disrupt chloride conductance.

This leads to thick, sticky mucus in the airways and other organs due to abnormal salt and water transport.

  • Option c: The mucociliary escalator relies on normal hydration of the airway surfaces to transport mucus and trapped particles out of the respiratory tract.

In CF, the defective CFTR protein causes dehydration of airway surfaces due to abnormal chloride and sodium ion transport, leading to thick mucus.

This thickened mucus impairs the mucociliary escalator, increasing the risk of infections and chronic lung disease.

  • Option d: Since all the above statements are correct and describe key aspects of cystic fibrosis, this is true option.

questions.text: A child has ingested cyanide from her parents' garage and is rushed to the emergency room. Which of the following components of the citric acid cycle will be depleted first in this child?
questions.solution:
Cyanide poisoning inhibits cytochrome c oxidase (Complex IV) in the electron transport chain (ETC). This blocks the terminal step of oxidative phosphorylation, where electrons are transferred to oxygen, effectively halting ATP production. As a result:

Electron flow through the ETC stops: The upstream components of the ETC, including NADH dehydrogenase (Complex I), become saturated with electrons.

NADH accumulates, and NAD+ is depleted: The lack of NAD+, a necessary cofactor, disrupts the citric acid cycle (TCA cycle) because several key steps require NAD+ to accept electrons (e.g., isocitrate dehydrogenase, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, malate dehydrogenase).

Option B & C) Citrate synthase, aconitase, and other enzymes of the TCA cycle remain functional, but the cycle stalls because of NAD+ depletion. Citrate production and acetyl-CoA metabolism are indirectly affected as the TCA cycle halts.

Thus, the NAD+ co-factor is depleted first, initiating the metabolic disruption caused by cyanide poisoning.

questions.text: Which of the following structure is not forming the boundaries of the triangle of auscultation?

  • On the left side, the cardiac orifice of the stomach lies deep to the triangle, and in days before X-rays were discovered, the sounds of swallowed liquids were auscultated over this triangle to confirm the oesophageal tumour

Key takeaways:

Triangle of auscultation:

  • Respiratory sounds are better heard over this triangle on each side.
  • It is a small triangular interval bounded
    • Medially by the lateral border of the trapezius,
    • Laterally by the medial border of the scapula, and
    • Inferiorly by the upper border of the latissimus dorsi.
  • The floor of the triangle is formed by

    • The rhomboid major muscle

questions.text: Saphenous nerve is a branch of which of the following nerve?
questions.solution:
Key Points:

Saphenous nerve:

  • It is a branch of the posterior division of femoral nerve.
  • It pierces the deep fascia on the medial side of the knee between the sartorius and gracilis and runs downward in front of the great saphenous vein.
  • It supplies the skin on the medial side of the leg and medial border of the foot up to the ball of the big toe.
  • Infrapatellar branch of the saphenous nerve pierces the deep fascia on the medial side of the knee, curves downward and forward to supply the skin over the ligamentum patellae.
  • It is commonly gets injured during vene section or surgery of the great saphenous nerve.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man undergoes a nephrectomy for a suspected renal tumor. Gross examination of the tumor reveals a 4 cm well-circumscribed mass with a grayish-white color and a solid appearance. Histological examination reveals a tumor composed of cells with a low nuclear grade and a solid, alveolar architecture. The cells are cuboidal to polygonal in shape and have regular, small central nuclei, scanty cytoplasm and no atypia. What is the most likely diagnosis of the renal tumor?
questions.solution:
A) Clear cell renal cell carcinoma: Clear cell renal cell carcinoma is the most common subtype of renal cell carcinoma, characterized by cells with clear cytoplasm and distinct cell borders.

B) Papillary renal cell carcinoma: Papillary renal cell carcinoma is a subtype of renal cell carcinoma characterized by a papillary architecture and cells with a high nuclear grade.

C) Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma: Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma is a subtype of renal cell carcinoma characterized by cells with a pale, reticular cytoplasm and a distinct cell border.

D) Renal adenoma: Renal adenoma is a benign tumor of the kidney, characterized by cells with a low nuclear grade and a solid, alveolar architecture.

Key Takeaways:

  • Benign papillary or tubulopapillary, low nuclear grade lesions of the kidney, similar in morphology to classic papillary renal cell carcinoma (PRCC); however, they lack fibrous capsules and are ≤ 15 mm
  • Prevalent in damaged and injured kidneys
    • Could be related to a progenitor / stem cell-like renal tubular cell population that increases upon kidney damage
  • Postulated to be precursor lesions to PRCC
    • However, the prevalence of adenoma is much higher than of carcinoma, indicating that many of them do not progress.

choices.text: It is more sensitive than Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) staining
Smears can be screened faster, allowing quicker diagnosis
It provides a better identification of non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM)
It uses a fluorescent LED microscope to detect bacilli

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an advantage of using auramine-phenol fluorescent staining in the diagnosis of tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
• (A) It is more sensitive than Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) staining: This is true. Auramine-phenol staining is more sensitive than ZN staining and recommended for screening tuberculosis cases.
  • (B) Smears can be screened faster, allowing quicker diagnosis: This is true. The use of a fluorescent microscope allows faster screening (2 minutes for 100 fields).
  • (C) It provides a better identification of non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM): This is false. Auramine-phenol staining is specifically used for tuberculosis detection, not for identifying NTM, which may require other methods for clear differentiation.
  • (D) It uses a fluorescent LED microscope to detect bacilli: This is true. Auramine-phenol staining requires fluorescent microscopy, which uses a LED light source.

choices.text: EM provides highly sensitive detection even at low viral loads, making it suitable for early diagnosis.
EM has a low sensitivity and can only detect viruses when the viral load exceeds 10^7 virions/mL.
EM is inexpensive and can be easily applied for the detection of viruses in tissue cultures and direct specimen analysis.
EM can accurately identify all viruses due to its high specificity and can be used in cases where viruses are difficult to cultivate.

questions.text: Which of the following is a major limitation of using electron microscopy (EM) for detecting viruses in clinical specimens?
questions.solution:
• Option A: EM does not offer high sensitivity at low viral loads. It has a detection threshold of approximately 10^7 virions/mL, meaning it is not effective at detecting early infections with low viral concentration.
  • Option B: One of the major drawbacks of using EM for virus detection is its low sensitivity, which limits its ability to detect viruses unless the viral load is high, around 10^7 virions/mL.
  • Option C: EM is actually expensive and requires specialized equipment and expertise, making it difficult for widespread, routine use.
  • Option D: While EM can detect viruses and provide visualization, it has low specificity, and there are better techniques for detecting specific viral infections with higher accuracy.

Key Takeaways:

  • Electron microscopy has low sensitivity and a high viral load requirement (10^7 virions/mL) for detection.
  • It is useful for viruses that are hard to culture, but it is expensive and not widely used in clinical practice due to these limitations.
  • Better alternatives, such as PCR or antigen detection, provide higher sensitivity and specificity.

questions.text:
A 54 year old Black woman was admitted to the hospital because of joint pain and a rash are of erythematous maculopapular lesions on her neck, upper chest, and elbows. The patient was diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus 5 months earlier and had been receiving piroxicam since then.
After further exams, another drug was added to her current pharmacotherapy. Which of the following drugs would be appropriate to administer at this time?
questions.solution:
• The pharmacotherapy of SLE includes nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), antimalarials, immunosuppressants, and glucocortcoids.
  • Anti-malarials such as hydroxychloroquine are especially effective when the disease is mild and skin manifestations are prominent, as in this case.
  • This drug has been shown to prevent relapses and to reduce morbidity and mortality.
  • The mechanism of action of hydroxychloroquine is still unclear but is likely related to its antiinflammatory properties.
  • A combination of an antimalarial and an NSAID is sometimes used in mild cases.
  • However, a combination of glucocorticoids and immunosuppressive drugs is a first-line pharmacotherapy for treatment of severe SLE.

Uses

  1. Oral CQ causes rapid fever clearance and disappearance of parasitaemia in patients of malaria caused by all P.ovale and P.malariae, most P.vivax and some P.falciparum that are still sensitive.
  2. Extraintestinal amoebiasis
  3. Rheumatoid arthritis .
  4. Discoid lupus erythematosus—very effective; less valuable in systemic LE.
  5. Lepra reaction
  6. Photogenic reactions.
  7. Infectious mononucleosis: affords symptomatic relief.

Option A & B: Because the patient was already receiving an NSAID,

adding another drug of the same class would be irrational.

Option C: Antibiotics are of no value, unless an infection supervenes.

  • Key takeaway
  • The pharmacotherapy of SLE includes nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), antimalarials, immunosuppressants, and glucocortcoids.
  • Anti-malarials such as hydroxychloroquine are especially effective when the disease is mild and skin manifestations are prominent

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman had been on a ventilator for 5 days because of ventilatory failure due to polymyositis when the physician noted increasing endotracheal secretions and decreased oximetry. A bronchoscopy showed abundant mucus plugs filling the bronchial lumen. Suctioning of the bronchial tree was performed, and a drug was given to improve mucociliary clearance. Which of the following drugs was most likely administered?
questions.solution:
• A patient who is artificially ventilated cannot clear bronchial secretions, mainly because effective cough cannot be performed.
  • Beta-2 agonist drugs improve mucociliary clearance and are therefore often given to patients on articial ventilation to decrease airway resistance and to remove secretions from bronchial mucosa.
  • Inhaled albuterol would provide the fastest acting and most localized therapy for an acute attack.
  • Bronchodilators are the only drugs useful in terminating acute attack of bronchial asthma.

Adrenergic drugs (β2 agonists) act by:


  • By inhalational route, these are the fastest acting drugs.
  • Salbutamol (albuterol), metaproternol, and terbutaline are fast acting drugs by inhalational route (optimal particle size: 2-5 μm, deposition can be increased by holding the breath in inspiration)
  • They are used for aborting an attack of acute asthma.

Option A: Epinephrine, by activat ing β2 receptors, can improve mucociliary clearance but would cause several adverse effects in this patient due to its cardiovascular actions.

Option C: Ipratropium has bronchodilating activity but does not improve mucociliary clearance, although, unlike other anticholinergic drugs, it does not reduce bronchial secretions and therefore does not affect mucociliary clearance.

Option D: Leukotriene pathway inhibitors have no effect on mucociliary clearance.

  • Key takeaway
  • Beta-2 agonist drugs improve mucociliary clearance and are therefore often given to patients on articial ventilation to decrease airway resistance and to remove secretions from bronchial mucosa.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman was admitted to the hospital because of anorexia, malaise, jaundice, and right upper quadrant abdominal pain for the past 2 days. The woman, who was 2 months' pregnant, was diagnosed with hyperthyroidism 1 month ago and started an appropriate therapy. Pertinent lab results on admission included alanine aminotransferase of 410 U/L. Which of the following drugs most likely caused the patient's disorder?
questions.solution:
• The patient’s history, signs, and symptoms suggest that she was most likely suffering from propylthiouracil-induced toxic hepatitis.
  • Propylthiouracil induced toxic hepatit is occurs in about 1% of treated patients, is always severe, and can be lethal.
  • Thioamides include drugs like methimazole, carbimazole and propylthiouracil.
  • Agranulocytosis and aplastic anemia is serious side effect of all of these drugs but it is seen rarely. Lung fibrosis is not at all associated with use of the same drugs.
  • Propylthiouracil is associated with hepatotoxicity.
  • All the 3 drugs are teratogenic. Least teratogenic is propylthiouracil.

Adverse effects of Thioamides

  • Hypothyroidism and goiter

[Enlargement of thyroid is an indication of hypothyroidism and is due to excess feedback TSH production]

  • Gastrointestinal Intolerance
  • Skin rashes
  • Joint pain
  • Liver damage can occur [especially with propylthiouracil]
  • Loss or graying of hair
  • Loss of taste and fever [infrequent]

Agranulocytosis [Rare but serious adverse effect]

Option A: Methimazole-induced liver injury is extremely rare. In addition, propylthiouracil is preferred over methimazole in the first trimester of pregnancy because it crosses the placenta much less than methimazole.

Option B & D: Liver injury with these drugs is negligible.

  • Key takeaway
  • Propylthiouracil is associated with hepatotoxicity.

questions.text: A 24-year-old obese woman in her 26th week of pregnancy was diagnosed with gestational diabetes mellitus after a positive glucose tolerance test. Dietary management failed to control the blood glucose, and her physician decided to prescribe an anti-diabetic therapy. Which of the following drugs would be most appropriate for the patient at this time?
questions.solution:
• Gestational diabetes mellitus is defined as any glucose intolerance that develops or is recognized during pregnancy, regardless of severity or time of onset.
  • Gestational diabetes is one of the most common maternal medical complication during pregnancy.
  • Because gestational diabetes carries several risks for both the mother and the offspring, treatment is mandatory.
  • Most gestational diabetics can control their glucose level with diet and regular exercise; drug therapy is needed only if these procedures are failing, as in this case.
  • Insulin is the hypoglycemic drug of choice during pregnancy because it does not cross the placenta and has an established safety record for both mother and fetus.

Indications of insulin

  1. All patients of type 1 DM
  2. Uncontrolled patients of type 2 DM
  3. Diabetes in pregnancy
  4. Diabetic Ketoacidosis
  • Insulin is effective in all forms of diabetes mellitus and is a must for type 1 cases, as well as for post pancreatectomy diabetes and gestational diabetes.
  • Many type 2 cases can be controlled by lifestyle measures like diet, reduction in body weight and appropriate exercise supplemented, if required, by oral antidiabetics.

Insulin is needed by such patients when:

  • Not controlled by diet and exercise or when these are not practicable.
  • Primary or secondary failure of oral antidiabetics or when these drugs are not tolerated.
  • Underweight patients.
  • Temporarily to tide over infections, trauma, surgery, pregnancy. In the perioperative period and during labour, monitored i.v. insulin infusion is preferable.
  • Any complication of diabetes, e.g. ketoacidosis, nonketotic hyperosmolar coma, gangrene of extremities.

Option A, B & C: All of these agents are not preferred in Gestational diabetes

Key Takeaway

  • Insulin is the hypoglycemic drug of choice during pregnancy because it does not cross the placenta and has an established safety record for both mother and fetus.

questions.text: A patient with HIV on treatment with tenofovir, lamivudine, and atazanavir/ritonavir is diagnosed with tuberculosis. Which of the following TB drugs should be changed to avoid drug interactions?
questions.solution:
• Rifampin is a strong inducer of the hepatic P-450 system and can increase the metabolism of many drugs, including glucocorticoids, oral contraceptives, methadone, β-blockers, and warfarin.

Interactions

  • Rifampin is a microsomal enzyme inducer—increases several CYP450 isoenzymes, including CYP3A4, CYP2D6, CYP1A2 and CYP2C subfamily.
  • It thus enhances its own metabolism (area under the plasma concentration-time curve is reduced by ~35%) as well as that of many drugs like
    • Warfarin
    • Oral contraceptives
    • Corticosteroids
    • Sulfonylureas
    • Hiv protease inhibitors
    • Non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs)
    • Theophylline
    • Metoprolol
    • Fluconazole
    • Ketoconazole
    • Clarithromycin
    • Phenytoin

Key takeaway

  • Rifampin is a strong inducer of the hepatic P-450 system and can increase the metabolism of many drugs, including glucocorticoids, oral contraceptives, methadone, β-blockers, and warfarin.

questions.text: Which of the following pair is incorrectly matched regarding potential teratogenicity of a drug if given during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• Lamivudine is generally well tolerated and has good safety profile, because of which it is accorded high priority in use for HIV.
  • Side effects are few-headache, fatigue, rashes, nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain.
  • Pancreatitis and neuropathy are rare. Hematological toxicity does not occur.
  • The 4th to 10th week of gestation is the period when fetal organs are developed.
  • Teratogenic drugs may cause fetal malformations if taken by a pregnant woman during this interval.
  • These malformations include cleft palate, malformation of fingers and toes, heart defects, facial abnormalities, and skeletal deformities.
  • Drug-induced jaundice is primarily of concern during the last trimester of pregnancy.

Drugs can affect the foetus at 3 stages

  • Fertilization and implantation Conception to 17 days-failure of pregnancy which often goes unnoticed.
  • Organogenesis 18 to 55 days of gestation, most vulnerable period, deformities are produced.
  • Growth and development 56 days onwards developmental and functional abnormalities can occur

Teratogenic Drugs


Key takeaway

  • Lamivudine is generally well tolerated and has good safety profile, because of which it is accorded high priority in use for HIV.

questions.text: A patient working in the glass industry came with complaints of hair loss and butterfly distribution of rashes over the face. His wife mentions that she has noticed some behavioural changes. The doctor saw a loss of eyebrows on the lateral side. Which of the following specific antidotes may be used in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of exposure from the glass industry, hair loss, butterfly distribution of rashes (maculopapular) over the face, loss of eyebrows on the lateral side along with behavioral and nail changes point to thallium poisoning and the specific antidote used in the management of this patient is Prussian blue.

  • Thallium poisoning occurs due to an overdose or idiosyncrasy. Thallium sulfate and thallium acetate are the two salts of thallium used in dyes, in the glass industry, and as rodenticides and pesticides. Treatment is mainly by stomach wash with potassium iodide or Prussian blue, activated charcoal. Hemodialysis is useful and forced diuresis can be given.
  • Mild cases of poisoning have features of joint pain, loss of appetite, and drowsiness. Severe cases present with colic, vomiting, muscle pain, convulsions, psychosis, tremors, delirium, and coma are seen in severe cases. Hair loss is seen after 2 weeks and a characteristic feature is the loss of the outer thirds of the eyebrows.
  • Mees lines can also be seen on the nails. Maculopapular rashes in a butterfly pattern on the face are characteristic.
  • In chronic poisoning, alopecia, skin rashes, peripheral neuropathy, and mental confusion are present.

The image below shows Mees's lines.

questions.text: What is the normal depth of anterior chamber in an adult eye?
questions.solution:
• The anterior chamber is filled with aqueous humour, bordered by the cornea in front, the iris, and the anterior surface of the lens
  • The angle of the anterior chamber is formed by the root of the iris and the ciliary body posteriorly, and the corneosclera anteriorly.
  • The canal of Schlemm, located in the sclera, is crucial for draining aqueous humour.
  • The trabecular meshwork, found at the angle, is made of collagen and elastic components, with perforated bands allowing aqueous flow into the canal of Schlemm.
  • The Schlemm's canal endothelial cells form gaps, contributing minimally to aqueous drainage, while major drainage occurs through giant vacuoles.
  • The anterior chamber depth is around 5 mm in adults, but it is shallower in children and older adults.

questions.text: Which of the following is the first-line treatment for xerophthalmia?
questions.solution:
Xerophthalmia

Definition:

Xerophthalmia refers to all ocular manifestations caused by vitamin A deficiency, affecting the conjunctiva, cornea, and sometimes the retina. It also includes biophysical disorders of retinal rods and cones.

Etiology:

Caused by dietary vitamin A deficiency or defective absorption. It is commonly associated with protein-energy malnutrition (PEM) and infections.

WHO Classification (1982):

  • XN: Night blindness
  • X1A: Conjunctival xerosis
  • X1B: Bitot’s spots
  • X2: Corneal xerosis
  • X3A: Corneal ulceration (less than 1/3 corneal surface)
  • X3B: Corneal ulceration (more than 1/3 corneal surface)
  • XS: Corneal scar
  • XF: Xerophthalmic fundus

Clinical Features:

  • XN: Night blindness, the earliest symptom
  • X1A: Dry, nonwettable patches on the conjunctiva
  • X1B: Raised, silvery white Bitot’s spots
  • X2: Punctate keratopathy, hazy cornea
  • X3A/X3B: Corneal ulcers/keratomalacia, potentially leading to blindness
  • XS: Corneal scars
  • XF: Seed-like whitish lesions on the fundus

Treatment:

  • Local Ocular Therapy: Artificial tears for conjunctival xerosis; bacterial treatment for corneal ulcers
  • Vitamin A Therapy:
    • For children over 1 year: 200,000 IU orally or 100,000 IU by injection
    • For children under 1 year or weighing less than 8 kg: Half the adult dose
    • Pregnant women or those of reproductive age with night blindness or conjunctival xerosis: 10,000 IU daily for 2 weeks
  • Treatment of underlying conditions: PEM, infections, dehydration, etc.

Prophylaxis:

  • Short-term approach: Periodic vitamin A supplementation
    • Infants (6-12 months) and children <8 kg: 100,000 IU every 3-6 months
    • Children 1-6 years: 200,000 IU every 6 months
    • Lactating mothers: 20,000 IU at delivery
  • Medium-term approach: Vitamin A food fortification
  • Long-term approach: Promote vitamin A-rich foods (e.g., leafy vegetables, papaya, drumsticks) and nutritional education.

questions.text: Which of the following premalignant lesion has the highest chance of transformation into malignancy?
questions.solution:
• The term oral erythroplakia is used to describe a red plaque or macular lesion in the mouth for which a specific clinical diagnosis cannot be established.
  • Lesions are named erythroleukoplakia, leukoerythroplakia or speckled leukoplakia when red and white areas are associated or white patches are present over the red plaque.
  • The World Health Organization (WHO) currently employs the term speckled leukoplakia to describe mouth lesions that present erythroplasic and leukoplasic components.
  • Oral erythroplasia is rare, but its malignant transformation rate is the highest among all of the precancerous lesions in the mouth; dysplasia, in situ carcinoma or invasive carcinoma may be found in over 90% of cases.
  • Although the potential for malignant transformation is higher in erythroplakia, speckled leukoplakia should not be neglected, since the red patches in this lesion have a similar histology to homogeneous erythroplakia.
  • Thus the chances of malignant transformation of erythroplakia is more than that of OSMF, Leukoplakia and oral lichen planus thus option A C and D are not true and option B is true.

Decreased salivation and loss of taste sensations in the anterior two third of the tongue
Decreased lacrimation and loss of taste sensations in the anterior two third of the tongue

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms may appear in the patient with fracture of the spine of the sphenoid bone?
questions.solution:
Spine of sphenoid:

  • It is a small sharp bony projection posterolateral to the foramen spinosum (greater wing of sphenoid).
  • The spine of the sphenoid is related laterally to the auriculotemporal nerve.
  • Medially it is related to the chorda tympani nerve and auditory tube.
  • Its tip provides attachment to the sphenomandibular ligament, anterior ligament of malleus and pterygospinous ligament.
  • Its anterior aspect gives origin to the most posterior fibres of the tensor veli palatini and tensor tympani muscles.

Fracture/necrosis of spine of sphenoid:

  • Two nerves are related to the spine of sphenoid: auriculotemporal nerve on its lateral aspect and chorda tympani on its medial aspect.
  • Both these nerves carry secretomotor fibres to salivary glands.
  • The auriculotemporal nerve to the parotid and chorda tympani to the submandibular and sublingual salivary glands.
  • Both these nerves would be damaged following fracture or necrosis of the spine.
  • This will result in decreased salivation and loss of taste sensations in the anterior two-third of the tongue.

Key Points:

Fracture/necrosis of spine of sphenoid:

  • Two nerves are related to the spine of sphenoid: auriculotemporal nerve on its lateral aspect and chorda tympani on its medial aspect.
  • Both these nerves carry secretomotor fibres to salivary glands.
  • The auriculotemporal nerve to the parotid and chorda tympani to the submandibular and sublingual salivary glands.
  • Both these nerves would be damaged following fracture or necrosis of the spine.
  • This will result in decreased salivation and loss of taste sensations in the anterior two-third of the tongue.

questions.text: Para-amino hippuric acid when passing through kidney, it does not go through which of the following mechanism?
questions.solution:
• Para-aminohippuric acid (PAH) is a compound often used in renal physiology studies to measure renal plasma flow because it is handled in a specific way by the kidneys.
  • Option b: PAH is not reabsorbed after it enters the renal tubule.

Significance: This lack of reabsorption ensures that PAH remains in the tubular fluid after filtration and secretion, which makes it ideal for measuring renal plasma flow.

  • Option a: PAH is freely filtered by the glomeruli, meaning it passes from the blood in the glomerular capillaries into Bowman’s space without restriction.
  • Option c: PAH is actively secreted into the renal tubules from the peritubular capillaries, primarily in the proximal tubule.

Significance: Nearly all PAH that is not filtered by the glomeruli is secreted into the tubules, ensuring its near-complete clearance from the plasma.

  • Option d: The term "excretion" refers to the final removal of a substance in the urine. Since PAH is neither reabsorbed nor metabolized, all the PAH filtered and secreted is excreted in the urine.

questions.text: All of the following are the causes of noncaseating granuloma except:
questions.solution:
Histoplasmosis is a fungal infection which shows Caseating granuloma.

A caseous granuloma is a type of chronic inflammatory response characterized by a necrotic center (caseation) surrounded by immune cells. It is often associated with infections like tuberculosis (TB) caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Histopathology:

  • Necrotic Core: The central area of a caseous granuloma contains necrotic tissue with a cheese-like (caseous) appearance, hence the name.
  • Macrophages: Around the core are activated macrophages, also known as epithelioid cells, which form a tight cluster.
  • Giant Cells: These are multinucleated cells formed by the fusion of macrophages, often seen at the periphery of the granuloma.
  • Lymphocytes: Surrounding the macrophages and giant cells are T-lymphocytes, which mediate the immune response.
  • Fibrosis: Over time, fibrous tissue may form around the granuloma as part of the healing process

Caseous granulomas are most commonly associated with tuberculosis, but they can also occur in other conditions like fungal infections (e.g., histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis), syphilis, and sarcoidosis.

Mechanism:

The body forms granulomas as an attempt to contain and isolate pathogens that are difficult to eradicate, such as mycobacteria. T-helper cells (Th1) release interferon-gamma (IFN-γ), activating macrophages to form granulomas.

Incorrect Options:

Non-caseating granulomas are a type of granulomatous inflammation that lack central necrosis (caseation). These granulomas are typically seen in a variety of diseases, often of immune or inflammatory origin.

Options A,B & D : All are the examples of Non caseating granuloma.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Caseating granuloma is seen in histoplasmosis.

questions.text: Which of the following diagnostic methods is considered the "gold standard" for confirming rabies infection?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Incorrect. The mouse inoculation test is a method of viral isolation but is not the gold standard for rabies diagnosis.
  • Option B: Correct. The DFA test is the gold standard due to its high sensitivity and specificity for detecting rabies antigens in tissues.
  • Option C: Incorrect. RT-PCR is a sensitive method but not considered the gold standard for rabies diagnosis, as DFA has higher specificity.
  • Option D: Incorrect. While Negri bodies are a key pathological sign, their absence does not rule out rabies, making the DFA test a more reliable diagnostic method.

Key Takeaway:

  • The DFA test, which detects rabies antigens, is the gold standard in rabies diagnosis, with superior sensitivity and specificity.

References:

  • Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Rabies. Available at: CDC Rabies Information
  • World Health Organization (WHO), Rabies Fact Sheet. Available at: WHO Rabies Fact Sheet

questions.text: A 54 year old woman is undergoing high-dose regimen with cyclophosphamide for breast cancer. As this treatment is particularly myelosuppressive, the oncologist is worried that her white blood cell count will drop dangerously low, making her susceptible to opportunistic infections. In addition to the chemotherapy, what is the oncologist likely to administer to prevent neutropenia?
questions.solution:
• Filgrastim is a recombinant form of granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) given to prevent chemotherapy-induced neutropenia.
  • Filgrastim is a recombinant G-CSF (Granulocyte- colony stimulating factor)
  • Pegylation of filgrastim help in increasing the duration of action of the drug.
  • These are used for leucopenia induced by cancer chemotherapy and are also useful for harvesting peripheral blood stem cells (these substances result in mobilization of stem cells from bone marrow to peripheral blood, which can be utilized for transplantation).
  • These drugs are administered by subcutaneous route

Summary of different growth factors


Option A: Epoetin alfa is commonly used to prevent anaemia while on chemotherapy.

Option C: Interferon alfa-2b is used in the management of specific leukemias and lymphomas.

Option D: Oprelvekin is an agent used to help treat chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia.

Key takeaway

  • Filgrastim is a recombinant form of granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) given to prevent chemotherapy-induced neutropenia.

questions.text: A 57 year old woman consulted her physician because of fever of 101°F, chills, nausea and vomiting, and pain in the upper right quadrant. Subsequent exams led to the diagnosis of acute cholecystitis. An appropriate therapy was started, including a cephalosporin that is primarily eliminated in the bile. Which of the following drugs was most likely administered?
questions.solution:
• The antibiotic therapy for acute cholecystitis is usually initiated to treat possible infection, but evidence of benefit is still modest .
  • Empiric therapy is directed against gramnegative enteric organisms such as Escherichia coli, Klebsiella, and Enterobacter species.
  • Cefoperazone and ceftriaxone are the two cephalosporins primarily eliminated with the bile.

Ceftriaxone

  • The distinguishing feature of this cephalosporin is its longer duration of action (t½ 8 hr), permitting once, or at the most twice daily dosing.
  • Penetration into CSF is good and elimination occurs equally in urine and bile.
  • Ceftriaxone has shown high efficacy in a wide range of serious infections including
    • Bacterial meningitis (especially in children),
    • Multiresistant typhoid fever,
    • Complicated urinary tract infections,
    • Abdominal sepsis and
    • Septicaemias.
  • A single 1.0 g i.m. dose is curative in gonorrhoea (including PPNG) and in chancroid.
  • Specific adverse effects
    • Hypoprothrombinaemia
    • Bleeding

Ceftriaxone is the first choice drug for

  • Gonorrhoea
  • Salmonellosis (including typhoid),
  • Coli sepsis
  • Proteus
  • Serratia
  • Haemophilus
  • Empirical therapy for bacterial meningitis.


Option A, C & D: These drugs are mainly eliminated by tubular secretion.

Key takeaway

  • The antibiotic therapy for acute cholecystitis is usually initiated to treat possible infection, Cefoperazone and ceftriaxone are the two cephalosporins primarily eliminated with the bile.

questions.text: All of the following are methods to assess contrast sensitivity in a patient, except:
questions.solution:
Contrast Sensitivity Testing

Definition:

Contrast sensitivity measures the ability to distinguish subtle changes in contrast and indirectly assesses the "quality" of vision. Unlike visual acuity, which tests sharpness under optimal conditions, contrast sensitivity tests how well a person can perceive objects in low-contrast situations (e.g., night driving or cloudy days).

Methods of Measurement:

  1. Letter Contrast Sensitivity:
    • Tested using charts like Pelli-Robson and Regan charts.
    • Contrast is reduced from 50% to 4%, and the patient is asked to identify the smallest letters possible.
    • The chart is placed 1 meter from the patient.
  2. Sinusoidal Grating Patterns:
    • Bars of varying tilt are presented to the patient, with decreasing contrast.
    • The patient identifies the direction of the tilt.
    • The Cambridge contrast sensitivity gratings use this method, where decreasing contrast is shown until the grating becomes indistinguishable from the background.

Clinical Indications:

  • Contrast sensitivity is especially useful for patients with normal visual acuity but impaired vision in low-contrast conditions (e.g., cataracts, refractive surgery).
  • It is a key test for optic nerve diseases like optic neuritis, multiple sclerosis, papilledema, and possibly glaucoma.
  • Contrast sensitivity also helps in monitoring visual changes over time.

Factors Affecting Contrast Sensitivity:

  • Age: Contrast sensitivity typically declines with age.
  • Refractive errors, glaucoma, diabetes, optic nerve diseases, and lenticular changes (e.g., cataracts) can also impair contrast sensitivity.
  • Even with normal visual acuity, contrast sensitivity may be reduced.

Common Charts for Measurement:

  • Arden Gratings
  • Cambridge Low-Contrast Gratings
  • Pelli-Robson Chart: Uses triplets of low-contrast letters.
  • Visitach Chart
  • Functional Acuity Contrast Test (FACT).

Importance:

Contrast sensitivity testing is essential for assessing visual function that cannot be evaluated by traditional visual acuity testing, particularly in conditions where fine detail perception in low-contrast situations is crucial.

questions.text: Germ Cells do not senesce because of
questions.solution:
Germ Cell, Stem cell and Cancer cells, telomeres do not shorten and the cells do not senesce. This is a result of the ribonucleoprotein telomerase which maintain telomeric length in these cells.

Eukaryotic cells during Replication process, removal of the RNA primer from the extreme 5' end of the lagging strand, there is no way to fill the remaining gap with DNA. Most normal human somatic cells, telomeres shorten with each successive cell division. Once telomere shorten beyond some cirtical length the cell is no longer to divide and is said to be senescent.

Telomerase contain a protein that acts as a reverse transcriptase and short piece of RNA tat acts as a template.

Option A) Presence of Ribonucleoprotein Endonuclease: This refers to enzymes involved in RNA processing and is unrelated to telomere maintenance.

Option B) Absence of Telomerase: The absence of telomerase leads to telomere shortening and senescence, which does not occur in germ cells.

Option D) Presence of Polymerase A: DNA polymerase α is involved in DNA replication but does not maintain telomeres.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a family history of ADPKD undergoes a renal biopsy. Histological examination reveals numerous cysts of varying sizes, lined by which of the following types of epithelial cells?
questions.solution:
A) Flat epithelial cells: Flat epithelial cells are typically seen in simple renal cysts.

B) Cuboidal epithelial cells: Cuboidal epithelial cells are typically seen in renal tubules and collecting ducts.

C) Columnar epithelial cells: Columnar epithelial cells are typically seen in the renal pelvis and ureters.

D) Hyperplastic epithelial cells with hobnail appearance: Hyperplastic epithelial cells with a hobnail appearance are characteristic of ADPKD, and are thought to contribute to the development of cysts.

Key Takeaways:

  1. Hyperplastic epithelial cells with a hobnail appearance are characteristic of ADPKD, and are thought to contribute to the development of cysts.
  2. Histological examination is essential for diagnosing ADPKD, as it allows for the identification of characteristic hyperplastic epithelial cells.

questions.text: Which of the following is the reason for the Eosinophilic appearance of necrotic cells in H & E stain?
questions.solution:
Necrotic cells show increased eosinophilia in H & E stain which is attributable to loss of cytoplasmic RNA and due to accumulation of denatured cytoplasmic proteins which binds to red dye eosin.

Necrosis is a pathological event that is the consequence of severe injury.

Necrosis is characterized by

  • denaturation of cellular proteins
  • leakage of cellular contents through damaged membranes
  • local inflammation due to enzymatic digestion of lethally injured cells

Early Morphological changes in necrosis:

  • Increased eosinophilia
  • Glassy homogenous appearance (due to loss of glycogen)
  • Vacuolated cytoplasm (moth eaten appearance)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common causative agent of actinomycetoma in India?
questions.solution:
