questions.text: The method of autopsy carried out en-masse to remove organs from tongue to prostate is:
questions.solution:
• Letulle technique is named after Maurice Letulle, which involves the removal of organs together in one mass from tongue to prostate.
    • This method of autopsy is thus also called "en masse."
    • The anatomy of the organs and organ systems can be preserved in the greatest possible way due to this.
    • Forensic pathologists can get a better overall picture due to the preservation of anatomical linkages.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A -Virchow technique: This approach is named after Rudolf Virchow. Instead of removing all organs at once, this method involves the sequential removal and examination of individual organs. The Virchow technique does not fit the description in the question because it does not involve the "en masse" removal of organs.
  • Option B - Rokitansky technique: In situ dissection (inside the body itself) is done in the Rokitansky technique.
  • Option C - Ghon's technique: Anatomical relationships are maintained by using the Ghon's approach, often known as "en bloc." Instead of one enormous block, the thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed using this procedure in three separate blocks. The dissection is made much more manageable by dividing the huge block into these three portions while still keeping the anatomy between the organs.

Key Takeaways: Letulle technique is named after Maurice Letulle, which involves the removal of organs together in one mass from tongue to prostate.

questions.text:
Pick the right answer.
Statement 1: The internal organs in a mummified body become shrunken, hard, dry, dark brown and become a single mass.
Statement 2: Mummification occurs in bodies buried in deep graves where evaporation of body fluids is very rapid
Statement 3: Continuous action of moist air is necessary for mummification
Statement 4: Chronic arsenic or antimony poisoning favors mummification
Statement 5: The entire body loses weight up to 60 to 70 % during the process of mummification
questions.solution:
The correct statements are 1, 4, and 5.

  • Mummification is a modification of putrefaction. Dehydration or drying and shriveling of the cadaver occurs from water's evaporation, but the body's natural appearance and general facial features are preserved. It begins in the exposed parts of the body like the face, hands, and feet. Then it extends to the entire body including the internal organs which may later disappear due to putrefaction and maggot activity. During the process of mummification, the whole body loses weight up to 60 to 70% and all the internal organs become a single mass.
  • Factors necessary for the production of mummification are the absence of moisture in the air and the continuous action of dry or warm air. It occurs in bodies buried in shallow graves in dry sandy soils, where evaporation of body fluids is very rapid due to the hot dry winds in summer. Chronic arsenic or antimony poisoning 1 favors the process.
  • Differential decomposition is a condition in which some parts of the body show mummification and other parts show adipocere formation.

questions.text: Which drug used in the treatment of VL is administered as 150 mg/day orally for 28 days and has a mechanism of action involving interaction with lipids and inhibition of cytochrome C oxidase?
questions.solution:
• Option A: This is incorrect. Pentavalent antimonials are administered IM or IV, not orally, and have a different mechanism of action involving oxidative stress.
  • Option B: This is incorrect. Liposomal amphotericin B is administered IV, not orally, and works by disrupting the cell membrane.
  • Option C: This is correct. Miltefosine is administered orally at 150 mg/day for 28 days and works by interacting with lipids and inhibiting cytochrome C oxidase.
  • Option D: This is incorrect. Paromomycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic administered IM and does not have the described mechanism of action.

Drugs Used in the Treatment of Visceral Leishmaniasis (VL)

  1. Pentavalent Antimonials
    • Dosage: Administered at 20 mg/kg per day, either intramuscularly (IM) or intravenously (IV), for 30 days.
    • Mechanism of Action: Pentavalent antimonials are converted to their active trivalent form within the body. This form induces oxidative stress in the parasite, leading to its destruction.
    • Resistance: Resistance to pentavalent antimonials has been reported, particularly in Bihar, India. Consequently, their use is now restricted to regions where resistance has not emerged.
  2. Liposomal Amphotericin B
    • Dosage: Given at 3-5 mg/kg per day via IV infusion for 3-5 days, up to a total dose of 15 mg/kg.
    • Mechanism of Action: This drug disrupts the parasite's cell membrane by forming pores, leading to cell death.
    • Use: It is the current drug of choice, especially in areas where resistance to antimonials has been reported.
  3. Miltefosine
    • Dosage: Administered orally at 150 mg/day for 28 days.
    • Mechanism of Action: Miltefosine acts by interacting with lipids and inhibiting cytochrome C oxidase, disrupting the parasite's energy metabolism.
    • Resistance: Resistance is rare but has been reported in India and Nepal.
  4. Paromomycin
    • Dosage: Given IM at 15 mg/kg per day for 21 days.
    • Mechanism of Action: Paromomycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic with anti-leishmanial activity, disrupting protein synthesis in the parasite.
  5. Immunotherapy
    • Interferon-γ: Used in cases where antimonial resistance is present or for selected relapse cases. It has been used in Kenya, Brazil, and India.

questions.text: Which of the following types of chemical indicators is used to check the efficacy of air removal, air leaks, and steam penetration in steam sterilizers?
questions.solution:
• A) Class I (Exposure Indicator): Class I indicators are used to show that the pack has been exposed to the sterilizing agent, but they do not guarantee sterility or check the efficacy of sterilization parameters like steam penetration. They are external indicators.
  • B) Class II (Bowie-Dick test): This is the correct answer. Class II indicators, also known as the Bowie-Dick test, are used to check the efficacy of air removal, air leaks, and steam penetration within the sterilizer. It ensures that the sterilizer is functioning properly.
  • C) Class IV (Internal pack control): Class IV indicators are used to monitor critical sterilization parameters, but they do not specifically check for steam penetration or air removal. They are placed inside the packs to verify the conditions inside.
  • D) Class V (Internal pack control indicator): Class V indicators, like Class IV, are internal indicators placed inside the packs to verify that the sterilization parameters are met, but they are not designed to evaluate the function of the sterilizer like the Bowie-Dick test.

Key Takeaways:

  • Class II (Bowie-Dick test) is used to evaluate the proper functioning of the steam sterilizer, particularly for air removal and steam penetration.
  • Class I indicators only show exposure to sterilants and do not guarantee sterility.
  • Class IV and V indicators monitor conditions inside the sterilization packs but do not check the sterilizer's functioning.

questions.text: What is the characteristic progression of paralysis in paralytic poliomyelitis?
questions.solution:
• Option A: This is incorrect. In paralytic poliomyelitis, paralysis begins in the proximal muscles and progresses to the distal muscles, not the other way around.
  • Option B: Correct. In paralytic poliomyelitis, the paralysis typically starts in the proximal muscles (such as the hip muscles) and then progresses towards the distal muscles (such as the feet). This leads to a characteristic tripod sign.
  • Option C: This is incorrect. Paralysis in poliomyelitis is typically asymmetric and affects the proximal muscles first, not symmetrically.
  • Option D: This is incorrect. Paralysis in poliomyelitis progresses over time and does not lead directly to respiratory failure. Only severe cases with bulbar involvement can result in respiratory insufficiency.

Key Takeaway:

  • Paralytic poliomyelitis progresses from the proximal to the distal muscles.
  • The characteristic tripod sign is seen due to paralysis starting at the hip and affecting the extremities.
  • This progression helps in diagnosing the disease clinically.

questions.text: In a healthy human positron emission tomographic scan indicates the pain activates the primary and secondary somatosensory cortex. Which of the following is not true about secondary somatosensory cortex?
questions.solution:
• Secondary somatosensory cortex is located in the wall of the lateral fissure (also called sylvian fissure) that separates the temporal from the frontal and parietal lobes.
  • Option b: The discriminative aspect of pain (e.g., identifying the location, intensity, and quality of the pain) is processed by the primary somatosensory cortex (S1). It is not a function of secondary somatosensory area.
  • Option a: The secondary somatosensory cortex (S2) is involved in higher-order processing of somatosensory information. It connects with the reticular formation and limbic system, mediating the emotional and motivational aspects of pain.
  • Option c: S2 is crucial for processing the motivational and affective components of pain, which are related to emotional experiences and behavioral responses. These components are part of the pain experience processed through connections to the limbic system.
  • Option d: The secondary somatosensory cortex is often abbreviated as S2.

questions.text: A 16-year-old female visited the skin specialist for white patches on the skin present since birth. After investigation patient was referred to imuunotherapist for expert opinion. It was found that patient has congenital defect in the migration of pigment cell precursors from the neural crest during embryonic development. Probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• Option d: Piebaldism is a congenital genetic disorder caused by mutations leading to defects in the migration and survival of melanocyte precursors from the neural crest during embryonic development.
  • It results in stable, non-progressive patches of depigmented skin and hair present at birth.
  • Option a: Vitiligo is an acquired autoimmune disorder characterized by the destruction of melanocytes, leading to depigmented patches of skin. It is not associated with a congenital defect in the migration of pigment cells. This condition appear at any age.
  • Option b: Albinos have a congenital inability to synthesize melanin resulting from a variety of different genetic defects in the pathways for melanin synthesis.
  • Option c: Pituitary adenomas are benign tumors of the pituitary gland that can cause hormonal imbalances. While they may lead to hyperpigmentation or hypopigmentation due to hormonal effects, they are unrelated to melanocyte migration or congenital conditions.

questions.text: A patient taking Clindamycin for a long period of time presented with diarrhea. Which of the following is the causative organism for this?
questions.solution:
Clostridium difficile (C. difficile) is the most common causative organism for antibiotic-associated diarrhea, especially after prolonged use of antibiotics like Clindamycin. It can lead to pseudomembranous colitis.

  • Cl. Botulinum (Option A) causes botulism.
  • Cl. Tetani (Option B) causes tetanus.
  • Cl. Perfringens (Option D) causes gas gangrene and food poisoning but is not the primary cause of antibiotic-associated diarrhea.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man has been charged for statutory rape. Which of the following Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023 (BNS) section is applicable in this case?
questions.solution:
The Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023 (BNS) section pertaining to statutory rape (act of sexual intercourse with a person under the age of consent) is 65.

This section is further divided into:

  • 65.(1) Whoever, commits rape on a woman under sixteen years of age shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than twenty years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life.
  • 65.(2) Whoever, commits rape on a woman under twelve years of age shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than twenty years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life or death.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding Tuberculous otitis media?
questions.solution:
Tuberculous otitis media in most of the cases the infection occurs secondary to pulmonary TB. The infection reaches the middle ear through eutachian tube.

Clinical features:

  1. painless ear discharge : Ear ache is characteristically absent. Discharge is often foul smelling.

questions.text: Which of the following is mainly treated by speech therapy?
questions.solution:
• Reinke edema is a benign disorder of the vocal folds defined by swelling of the superficial lamina propria, also known as the Reinke space. Procedural treatment options for Reinke edema include cold steel excision, CO2 laser, microdebridement, photoangiolytic laser, and intralesional injection. Thus option A is not true.
  • The vocal process granuloma is a nonneoplastic lesion that most often develops in the vicinity of the posterior vocal cords, adjacent to the vocal process. It may be an ulcerated region of the cord. Treatment includes Microlaryngoscopic removal. Thus option b is not true.
  • Hemorrhagic vocal polyps are the most commonly encountered benign lesions of the vocal fold. The hyperfunctional glottal sound production causes shearing stress, leading to capillary bleeding within the SLP. The resulting malformed neovascularized mass can be easily ruptured, leading to hemorrhagic events within the vocal fold. Treatment includes Microlaryngoscopic removal. Thus option c is not true.
  • Vocal cord nodules, sometimes called singer's or screamer's nodes, can form if you're repeatedly misusing or overusing your voice. These callus-like growths develop in the midpoint of your vocal cords. This part of the vocal cords gets used most often when you're using your voice. Often, nodules develop on both vocal cords. Main treatment here is speech therapy. Thus option D is correct.

questions.text: Which of the following structure is not forming the boundary of the superior thoracic aperture?
questions.solution:
Inlet of thorax:

  • The thoracic cavity communicates with the root of the neck through a narrow opening called superior thoracic aperture or thoracic inlet.
  • Boundaries:
    • Anteriorly: Superior border of manubrium sterni.
    • Posteriorly: Anterior border of the superior surface of the body of T1 vertebra.
    • Laterally (on each side): Medial border of first rib and its cartilage.
  • The upper end of anterior boundary lies 1.5 inches below the upper end of posterior boundary because first rib slopes downwards and forwards from its posterior end to anterior end.
  • Therefore, plane of thoracic inlet slopes (directed) downwards and forwards with an obliquity of about 45°.
  • The upper border of manubrium sterni lies at the level of upper border of T3 vertebra.

Key Points:

  • Boundaries of the inlet of the thorax:
    • Anteriorly: Superior border of manubrium sterni.
    • Posteriorly: Anterior border of the superior surface of the body of T1 vertebra.
    • Laterally (on each side): Medial border of first rib and its cartilage.

questions.text: In case of splenomegaly, spleen enlarges towards right iliac fossa due to which of the following fold of peritoneum?
questions.solution:
Ligaments of the spleen:

  • The spleen is completely enclosed in the peritoneum except at its hilum, from where two peritoneal folds extend
    • One to the stomach called gastrosplenic ligament.
    • One to the left kidney called lienorenal ligament.
  • Gastrosplenic ligament:
    • It extends from the hilum of the spleen to the upper one-third of the greater curvature of the stomach. It contains short gastric vessels.
  • Lienorenal ligament:
    • It extends from the hilum of the spleen to the anterior surface of the left kidney.
    • It contains:
      • Tail of the pancreas
      • Splenic vessels
      • Pancreaticosplenic lymph nodes
  • Phrenicocolic ligament:
    • It is a triangular fold of the peritoneum which extends from the left colic flexure to the diaphragm opposite to the 10th
    • It passes below the lateral end of the spleen, which it supports; hence, it is also termed sustentaculum lienis.

Splenomegaly:

  • The enlargement of the spleen (splenomegaly) occurs in number of diseases.
  • The spleen may increase in size by as much as tenfold (massive splenomegaly).
  • The very large (massive) spleen projects downward and medially toward the right iliac fossa in the direction of the axis of the 10th rib. This is due to the phrenicocolic ligament is not allowing to move downwards towards left iliac fossa.The common causes of massive splenomegaly are:
    • Malaria
    • Cirrhosis of liver
    • Chronic myeloid leukemia
    • Kala-azar

questions.text: 60 years old male patient was diagnosed with the lateral medullary syndrome. Patient may have the ipsilateral paralysis of the all of the following group muscles, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Lateral medullary syndrome:

  • It is also known as Wallenburg syndrome.
  • It occurs due to blockage of posterior inferior cerebellar artery.
  • It supplies areas behind the inferior olivary nucleus.
  • Features are:
    • Ipsilateral paralysis of most of muscles of soft palate, pharynx and larynx due to injury to nucleus ambiguus which gives fibres to IX, X and XI cranial nerves.
    • Loss of pain and temperature on same side of face due to involvement of spinal nucleus and spinal tract of trigeminal nerve.
    • Loss of pain and temperature on opposite side of the body due to involvement of lateral spinothalamic tract.

Key Points:

questions.text:
A 40-year-old female with a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with symptoms of hypoglycemia. Laboratory results show:
1.Fasting plasma glucose: 50 mg/dL
2.Insulin level: 20 μU/mL
3.C-peptide level: 0.5 ng/mL
4.Glucagon level: 100 pg/mL
Which of the following laboratory findings indicates endogenous insulin production?
questions.solution:
C-peptide is a byproduct of endogenous insulin production, making it a useful indicator of residual beta-cell function.

C-peptide has several functions:

  1. Insulin production indicator: Measuring C-peptide levels can help determine if the body is producing enough insulin.
  2. Diabetes diagnosis and monitoring: C-peptide levels can help diagnose and monitor diabetes, as they can indicate the body's ability to produce insulin.
  3. Insulinoma diagnosis: High C-peptide levels can indicate the presence of an insulinoma, a rare tumor of the pancreas that produces excess insulin.
  4. Research applications: C-peptide is used in research studies to investigate insulin production, glucose metabolism, and diabetes.

Incorrect Options-

C,D.Glucagon level is not directly related to endogenous insulin production.

Key Takeaway: A Insulin level can be influenced by exogenous insulin administration

questions.text: A 65 year old patient on dialysis, kidney biopsy showing amyloid deposits in glomeruli and tubule interstitium. Which of the following precursor protein is responsible?
questions.solution:
Option A: Dialysis-related amyloidosis: Elevated β2M levels due to chronic kidney disease and long-term hemodialysis.

Option B: β2-transferrin is a glycoprotein, consisting of two polypeptide chains (β1 and β2) and two carbohydrate chains.

  • Function: It binds to iron and transports it from the intestine to the liver, spleen, and bone marrow.

Option C: β2glycoprotein is a protein found in the blood that plays a role in blood clotting and the immune system.

Abnormalities in β2 glycoprotein have been linked to various conditions, including:

  • Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS)
  • Thrombosis
  • Recurrent miscarriage
  • Lupus

Option D: Transthyretin (TTR) is a transport protein that carries thyroid hormones and vitamin A in the blood.

  • It's produced mainly in the liver and plays a crucial role in transporting these essential nutrients to various tissues and organs.
  • Abnormal TTR levels or function are associated with certain diseases, such as:
    • Familial amyloid polyneuropathy (FAP)
    • Familial amyloid cardiomyopathy (FAC)
    • Senile systemic amyloidosis (SSA)
  • These conditions often result from TTR misfolding and aggregation, leading to amyloid deposits in tissues.

Key Takeaways: Dialysis-related amyloidosis: Elevated β2M levels due to chronic kidney disease and long-term hemodialysis.

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple asymptomatic scaly patches varying in color from white to tan to brown to pink. On potassium hydroxide (KOH) wet mount, a spaghetti and meatball appearance was seen. Which of the following is the causative organism for this disease?
questions.solution:
The spaghetti and meatball appearance observed on KOH wet mount is characteristic of Malassezia furfur, a superficial fungal infection. The patient exhibits typical symptoms such as scaly patches of various colors (white, tan, brown, pink), which are indicative of pityriasis versicolor, a skin condition caused by Malassezia furfur.

  • Tinea corporis (Option A) is caused by dermatophytes, not Malassezia.
  • Sporotrichosis (Option C) and Blastomycosis (Option D) are caused by different fungi that do not produce the "spaghetti and meatball" appearance

questions.text: Methotrexate is a chemotherapeutic agent used in the treatment of breast cancer. It works by inhibiting the synthesis of which nucleotide?
questions.solution:
• Methotrexate (Mtx)
    • This folic acid analogue is one of the oldest and highly efficacious antineoplastic drugs which acts by inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase (DHFRase), thus blocking the conversion of Dihydrofolic acid (DHFA) to tetrahydrofolic acid (THFA).
    • Tetrahydrofolic acid is an essential coenzyme required for one carbon transfer reactions in de novo purine synthesis and amino acid interconversions.
  • Antimetabolites
    • These drugs act in the S-phase of cell cycle (CCS drugs), thus only dividing cells are responsive.
    • These drugs possess immunosuppressive properties apart from their antineoplastic effects.
  • Folic Acid Analogs
    • Methotrexate, pemetrexed and pralatrexate are the inhibitors of dihydrofolate reductase (DHFRase).
    • These drugs also inhibit thymidylate synthase (TS) and the enzymes involved in early purine synthesis.
  • Key takeaway
    • This folic acid analogue is one of the oldest and highly efficacious antineoplastic drugs which acts by inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase (DHFRase), thus blocking the conversion of Dihydrofolic acid (DHFA) to tetrahydrofolic acid (THFA).

questions.text: Which of the following tests is used to differentiate the cyanide poisoning from salicylates?
questions.solution:
Lee-Jones test is used to distinguish between Hydrogen cyanide and salicylate poisoning.

To 5 ml of stomach contents add a few crystals of ferrous sulphate and 5 drops of 2% sodium hydroxide. Boil and cool and add 10 drops of 10% hydrochloric acid. The greenish-blue color indicates cyanide and purplish color salicylates.

Cyanides are white powders used in many trades, in metallurgy, photography, electroplating, fumigation of ships and aircraft, etc. It inhibits the action of cytochrome oxidase, carbonic anhydrase. It blocks the final step of oxidative phosphorylation causing histotoxic anoxia.

This is the most rapid of all poisons. The breath has an odor of bitter almonds. With small doses, the person first experiences headache, confusion, giddiness, nausea, and some loss of muscular power. Massive doses may produce sudden loss of consciousness and prompt death from respiratory arrest.

The principle of treatment is to reverse the cyanide-cytochrome combination by converting hemoglobin to methemoglobin by giving nitrites.

Other options: They are examples of tests done to detect carbon monoxide.

Kunkel's test (Option A) or tannic acid test (Option D): If tannic acid is added to blood it remains cherry-red in CO

Hoppe-Seyler's test (Option C): A few drops of blood are added to a solution of 10% sodium hydroxide. Normal blood turns brownish-green, but if CO is present, the 1 color will remain pink.

questions.text: A 45 year old patient presented with Acute Chest pain suggestive of Angina & Coronary Insufficiency. He was managed medically and given treatment including Rosuvastatin. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Statin - Rosuvastatin, Atorvastatin, Simavastatin etc are potent inhibitor of Hydroxymethylglutaryl Coenzyme A reductase. The said enzyme is involved in conversation of cholesterol synthesis pathway -rate limiting stepi.e step involving 3 acetyl Co A to Mevalonic Acid. Along with Up-regulation of LDL receptors on hepatocytes, increasing the clearance of LDL cholesterol from the bloodstream &significant reduction in total cholesterol, LDL-C, and triglycerides

In above case scenario, Statins are given as prophylatically and also as part of treatment to minimize atherosclerosis changes in coronary arteries on longer run.

Option C) Activation of Lecithin Cholesterol Acyl Transferase (LCAT):

LCAT is an enzyme involved in the esterification of cholesterol in high-density lipoprotein (HDL). Statins do not act on this enzyme directly.

Option D) Inhibition of Lipoprotein Lipase:

Lipoprotein lipase breaks down triglycerides in lipoprotein. Statins do not directly inhibit this enzyme; their primary action is on cholesterol synthesis.

choices.text: Decreased smooth muscle tone in vessel walls

questions.text: Critical closing pressure in the circulatory system is primarily increased by:
questions.solution:
• Critical closing pressure is defined as the pressure at which blood flow ceases.
  • When the pressure in a small blood vessel is reduced, a point is reached at which no blood flows, even though the pressure is not zero. This is because the vessels are surrounded by tissues that exert a small but definite pressure on them, and when the intraluminal pressure falls below the tissue pressure, they collapse.
  • Option a: Increase in sympathetic activity increases smooth muscle contraction, causing vasoconstriction and raising the critical closing pressure, as more pressure is required to overcome the constriction and sustain blood flow.
  • Option b: Blood viscosity primarily influences vascular resistance rather than critical closing pressure. Reduced viscosity lowers resistance to flow but does not significantly impact the intraluminal pressure required to maintain patency in constricted vessels.
  • Option c: Increased compliance means the vessel walls are more elastic and can accommodate changes in pressure and volume without collapsing. This lowers the critical closing pressure by reducing the force needed to maintain vessel patency.
  • Option d: A decrease in smooth muscle tone results in vasodilation, lowering the pressure required to keep the vessel open and thereby reducing the critical closing pressure.

choices.text: Oxidation of Met358 amino acid in alpha 1 Antiproteinase
Mutation in Receptors for Alpha 1 antiproteinase

questions.text: Tobacco users or smokers are more prone to develop Emphysema after Infection due to
questions.solution:
• Individuals who use tobacco products or are regularly exposed to the smoke generated from burning fossil fuels are especially prone to oxidation of Met358.
  • In the lungs, oxidation of a key methionine residue, Met358, located in the protease-binding domain renders α1- antiproteinase unable to covalently bind and neutralize serine Proteases.
  • Individuals deficient in α-antiproteinase are also at greater risk of lung damage from the accumulation of polymorphonuclear white blood cells in the lung that occurs during pneumonia and other respiratory infections.
  • Deficiency of α1-antiproteinase is also implicated in α1antitrypsin deficiency liver disease, a form of cirrhosis that afflicts persons possessing the ZZ phenotype.
  • In these individuals, a mutation leading to the substitution of Glu342 by lysine produces a form of α1-antiproteinase that is prone to aggregation in the cisternae of the endoplasmic reticulum in hepatic cells.

questions.text: What immunological condition predisposes patients to malakoplakia?
questions.solution:
A) HIV infection

  • Can contribute, but not the sole factor.

B) Diabetes mellitus

  • Risk factor, but not primary cause.

C) Immunosuppression

  • Correct: Impaired immune response increases susceptibility.

D) Rheumatoid arthritis

  • Not a direct predisposing factor.

Key Takeaways:

  1. Malakoplakia is a rare inflammatory condition characterized by Michaelis-Gutmann bodies.
  2. Primarily affects immunocompromised patients.
  3. Most commonly associated with E. coli infections.
  4. Characterized by impaired macrophage bactericidal activity.
  5. Can present with various urinary symptoms.
  6. Requires comprehensive diagnostic approach.
  7. Treatment involves antibiotics and addressing underlying immunological issues.

questions.text: According to Spaulding's classification of medical devices, which of the following is the correct method of decontamination for critical devices (high risk) that enter a normally sterile site?
questions.solution:
Explanation of all options:

  • A) Sterilization: This is the correct answer. Critical devices are items that enter a normally sterile site (e.g., surgical instruments, implants, syringes), and they require sterilization to ensure complete elimination of all microbial life.
  • B) High-level disinfection (HLD): This method is used for semi-critical devices (e.g., respiratory equipment, flexible endoscopes) that come into contact with mucous membranes or body fluids, not for critical devices.
  • C) Low-level disinfection (LLD): This method is used for non-critical devices (e.g., blood pressure cuffs, stethoscopes), which only contact intact skin, not for critical devices.
  • D) Intermediate-level disinfection (ILD): This method is used for semi-critical devices, but not for critical devices. It is used for items that contact mucous membranes or body fluids.

Key Takeaways:

  • Critical devices require sterilization because they enter sterile sites and must be free of all microorganisms.
  • Devices classified as semi-critical or non-critical are cleaned using varying levels of disinfection based on their contact with body tissues.
  • Spaulding's classification helps determine the appropriate decontamination method based on the risk level associated with medical devices.

questions.text: A 51 year old woman at a routine checkup, was found to have a heart rate of 110 bpm. The woman had a history of atrial flutter for which she had been receiving quinidine for the past 2 weeks following a successful electrical cardioversion. The physician thought that her tachycardia was caused by quinidine. Which of the following actions best explains the mechanism of this adverse effect of quinidine?
questions.solution:
• Quinidine is still sometimes used to maintain the normal sinus rhythm after cardioversion, but it can cause paradoxical tachycardia, due to its anti-muscarinic action on the heart, which increases atrioventricular conduction.
  • Quinidine
    • It is the dextro isomer of the antimalarial alkaloid quinine found in cinchona bark.
    • In addition to Na+ channel blockade, quinidine has cardiac antivagal action which augments prolongation of atrial effective refractory period (ERP).
    • A-V node ERP is increased by direct action of quinidine, but decreased by its antivagal action; overall effect is inconsistent.
    • Quinidine depresses myocardial contractility; failure may be precipitated in damaged hearts.

Option B: Quinidine blocks, not activates, α 1 receptors, thus causing peripheral vasodilation.

Option C: By causing vasodilation, quinidine actually decreases the stimulation of arterial baroreceptors.

Option D: Quinidine can block, not activate both calcium and potassium channels.

  • Key Takeaway
    • Quinidine is used to maintain the normal sinus rhythm after cardioversion, but it can cause paradoxical tachycardia, due to its anti-muscarinic action on the heart, which increases atrioventricular conduction.

Stiff yellow necrosis in the pancreas

questions.text: An elderly man living alone was found dead in his wardrobe during winter. Upon further investigation, there was no heating equipment in his house. Identify the incorrect autopsy finding.
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette points towards hide-and-die syndrome due to hypothermia.

Autopsy does not show dark red deoxygenated blood. It shows bright red-colored blood due to the retention of oxygen by hemoglobin at low temperatures.

In very rare cases of hypothermic death, the disoriented, dying victim, to protect himself from the cold, may hide in corners, cupboards, or under piles of furniture. More commonly a naked or partly clothed old person. A close differential is a homicide or robbery.

Postmortem(PM) appearance externally shows brown-pink areas with indistinct margins, particularly over bony prominences. Extremities cyanosed and bright pink PM lividity.

Internally blood is often bright red, stomach mucosa shows numerous brown black erosions and ulcerations named as Wischnewsky spots. Fat necrosis of the pancreas is seen in 50% of cases. Perivascular hemorrhages in the brain and small infarcts in the heart are seen. Internal organs are congested.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a painful, red eye, blurred vision, and a history of contact lens use. On examination, there is a central corneal ulcer with a yellow-white infiltrate and hypopyon. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Bacterial Corneal Ulcers

Causative Organisms:

  • Bacterial corneal ulcers are often caused by pyogenic bacteria such as Pseudomonas, Staphylococcus aureus, Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Escherichia coli, and others.
  • gonorrhoeae and Corynebacterium diphtheriae are the only bacteria that can invade intact corneal epithelium. Other bacteria like pneumococci cause ulceration after epithelium damage.

Mode and Source of Infection:

  • Organisms typically enter through breaks in the corneal epithelium due to trauma, reduced resistance, or preexisting conditions (e.g., dry eyes, contact lenses, entropion).
  • Specific risk factors include trauma, steroid use, dry eyes, neurotrophic keratitis, and poor hygiene.

Pathology:

  • Corneal ulcer presents as a breach in the epithelium with necrosis of corneal layers.
  • The ulcer has a saucer shape with swelling around the edges, often surrounded by a grey zone of leucocyte infiltration.
  • Bacterial toxins irritate the iris and ciliary body, leading to keratouveitis and hypopyon.
  • Vascularization and immune response help control infection, leading to healing and potential scar formation.

Healing and Scarring:

  • As the ulcer heals, the necrotic material sheds, and the corneal tissue regenerates.
  • Fibrous tissue replaces the damaged corneal layers, leading to a scar. The scar may be opaque, especially if Bowman's membrane is destroyed.
  • Vascularization aids in healing, and scars can become more transparent over time.
  • In severe cases, corneal facets may remain, which can affect vision

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is brought to the emergency room with severe burns caused by a nearby explosion. Examination showed burns covering over 60% of his body surface area. Which type of blast injury is this consistent with?
questions.solution:
The blast injury is consistent with the quaternary blast injury. The injury following an explosion causing burns shall come under quaternary blast injury.

Classification of blast injuries:

Primary blast injuries- effect of transmitted blast waves causing overpressure type of injury. The middle ear, lungs, and gastrointestinal tract are the most susceptible. Eg: tympanic membrane injury, blast lung, intestinal blast injury.

Secondary blast injuries (the most common type of blast injury)- are caused by flying shrapnel or missiles and other airborne debris propelled by the explosion leading to penetrating/fragmentation type of injuries. These injuries may affect any part of the body.

Tertiary blast injuries- are caused by blast wind that can throw victims against solid objects. It causes blunt type of injuries. Eg: crush injuries and traumatic amputation.

Quaternary and Quinary blast injuries- all other injuries caused by explosions are not included in the above three categories. eg, flash burns, inhalational injuries, crush injuries. Quinary injuries

questions.text: Following are the causes of uniocular diplopia, except:
questions.solution:
Diplopia (Double Vision)

Diplopia is the perception of double images and can be classified into:

  • Uniocular Diplopia: Double vision in one eye, which occurs even when the other eye is closed.
    • Common causes include:
      • Subluxated lens
      • Double pupil
      • Incipient cataract
      • Keratoconus
      • Eccentric IOL (Intraocular Lens)
  • Binocular Diplopia: Double vision that occurs only when both eyes are open.
    • Common causes include:
      • Paralytic squint
      • Myasthenia gravis
      • Diabetes mellitus
      • Thyroid disorders
      • Blow-out fracture of the floor of the orbit
      • Anisometropic glasses (e.g., uniocular aphakic glasses)
      • After squint correction with abnormal retinal correspondence (paradoxical diplopia)

questions.text: All of the following are the major criteria in the Bent and kuhn criteria for allergic fungal rhinosinusitis except?
questions.solution:
Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis (AFRS) is an inflammatory disorder of the upper respiratory tract resulting from type 1 and 3 hypersensitivity reactions against fungi.

The Bent and Kuhn diagnostic criteria, which were reported in 1994 and are widely used for diagnosis of AFRS, is composed of the following five criteria:

  1. type 1 hypersensitivity to fungi confirmed by history, skin testing, or serology;
  2. nasal polyposis;
  3. characteristic signs on computed tomography (CT) described as serpiginous areas of increased attenuation;
  4. eosinophilic mucus without fungal invasion of sinus tissue;
  5. positive fungal stain of sinus contents removed during surgery.

Among these items, nasal polyposis is not always present, and the guideline issued by five US national societies specifies edema of the middle meatus or ethmoid area or nasal polyps. Thus option d is not true.

choices.text: The Trypanosoma cruzi parasite is transmitted to humans through the bite of the reduviid bug, which releases trypomastigotes directly into the bloodstream.
The reduviid bug becomes infected with T. cruzi when it feeds on a human, ingesting trypomastigotes, which transform into metacyclic trypomastigotes in the gut before being excreted.
In the human host, T. cruzi transforms into metacyclic trypomastigotes that circulate in the bloodstream, where they are ingested by the reduviid bug during its blood meal.
T. cruzi only transforms into the amastigote form in the bloodstream and never enters tissues like the heart, digestive system, or nervous system.

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes the transmission and life cycle of Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas' disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation of All Options:

  • Option A: T. cruzi is not directly transmitted through the bite of the reduviid bug. Instead, the bug transmits the parasite through its feces, which the host rubs into open skin or mucous membranes.
  • Option B: The reduviid bug becomes infected with T. cruzi after feeding on an infected host. The ingested trypomastigotes transform into metacyclic trypomastigotes in the gut of the bug, which are then excreted and can infect a new host.
  • Option C: The metacyclic trypomastigotes do not circulate in the bloodstream; they transform into amastigotes once inside human tissues, where they multiply.
  • Option D: T. cruzi amastigotes primarily infect tissues such as the heart, skeletal muscles, and the gastrointestinal system, causing chronic manifestations like cardiomyopathy and megaesophagus.

Key Takeaways:

  • The reduviid bug transmits cruzi by excreting metacyclic trypomastigotes after feeding on an infected host.
  • The amastigote form of cruzi primarily resides within tissues such as the heart, muscles, and gastrointestinal tract, where it replicates.
  • cruzi is a major cause of Chagas' disease, and understanding its life cycle helps in controlling transmission.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidelines on Trypanosoma cruzi..

choices.text: Secretes high levels of inhibin, leading to suppressed FSH
Exclusively produces estrogen without any hormonal feedback
Generates random hormone levels with no predictable pattern

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with postmenopausal vaginal bleeding and an ovarian mass. Pathology reveals a granulosa cell tumor. Which of the following statements best characterizes the hormonal profile of this tumor?
questions.solution:
A) Produces excessive testosterone, causing virilization

  • While some androgen production can occur, granulosa cell tumors are primarily estrogen-producing
  • Virilization is not a characteristic feature
  • Reasoning: Misunderstands the primary hormonal secretion pattern

B) Secretes high levels of inhibin, leading to suppressed FSH

  • Granulosa cell tumors characteristically produce high levels of inhibin
  • Inhibin selectively suppresses follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)
  • Mechanism:
    • Inhibin acts on the pituitary gland
    • Blocks FSH production through negative feedback
    • Creates a distinctive hormonal signature
  • Clinical Implications:
    • Can be used as a tumor marker
    • Helps in diagnosis and monitoring

C) Exclusively produces estrogen without any hormonal feedback - Estrogen production occurs, but not in isolation

  • Tumor has complex hormonal interactions
  • Inhibin plays a crucial role in hormonal regulation
  • Reasoning: Oversimplifies hormonal dynamics

D) Generates random hormone levels with no predictable pattern - Granulosa cell tumors have a predictable hormonal profile

  • Characterized by consistent estrogen and inhibin production
  • Reasoning: Misrepresents the tumor's hormonal characteristics

Advanced Pathophysiological Insights:

  • Granulosa cell tumors arise from ovarian granulosa cells
  • Typically low-grade malignant potential
  • Hormonally active tumors with predictable secretion patterns

Key Takeaways:

  1. Granulosa cell tumors primarily produce estrogen and inhibin
  2. Inhibin suppresses FSH through negative feedback
  3. Hormonal markers are crucial for diagnosis and monitoring

Clinical Correlations:

  • Can cause precocious puberty in young patients
  • Potential cause of postmenopausal bleeding
  • Useful tumor marker: Inhibin B levels

Diagnostic Considerations:

  • Serum estrogen levels elevated
  • Inhibin B as a specific tumor marker
  • Imaging studies to assess tumor extent

Molecular Mechanism:

  • FOXL2 gene mutations common
  • Impacts cell proliferation and hormonal regulation

questions.text: Which of the following organ in female reproductive system form from Mullerian duct?
questions.solution:
• Mullerian duct forms the internal genital organs in female.
  • Option b: The Mullerian ducts (paramesonephric ducts) develop into the uterus, fallopian tubes, and the upper portion of the vagina in females.
  • Option a: The ovaries develop from the genital ridge, not the Mullerian duct. The genital ridge gives rise to the gonads (testes in males, ovaries in females).
  • Option c: The clitoris forms from the genital tubercle, not the Mu8llerian duct.
  • Option d: The labia majora develops from the labioscrotal swellings, which are not derived from the Mullerian duct.

choices.text: VDRL is preferred for testing individual samples due to its prolonged shelf-life, whereas RPR is better suited for batch testing with large sample loads.
VDRL and RPR both detect reagin antibodies, but RPR provides faster results due to its ability to detect clumping without a microscope, making it ideal for batch testing.
The sensitivity of non-treponemal tests is higher in the late stage of syphilis, and they are useful in diagnosing congenital syphilis.
Non-treponemal tests detect T. pallidum specific antibodies, and therefore, they are more reliable than treponemal tests in the primary stage of syphilis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the use of non-treponemal tests like VDRL and RPR in the diagnosis of syphilis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of All Options:

  • Option A: VDRL is generally preferred for batch testing due to its ease of use in large volumes, whereas RPR is more suitable for individual testing since it offers quicker results and does not require a microscope.
  • Option B: Both VDRL and RPR test for reagin antibodies, but RPR is more efficient in individual sample testing due to its larger clumps and lack of need for a microscope. It is designed for faster results and is often used in settings with lower sample loads.
  • Option C: The sensitivity of non-treponemal tests is highest during the secondary stage of syphilis, not the late stage. They are also less reliable for diagnosing congenital syphilis, which typically requires treponemal tests.
  • Option D: Non-treponemal tests detect reagin antibodies, not T. pallidum-specific antibodies. Treponemal tests are the ones used for detecting antibodies specific to Treponema pallidum, especially in the primary stage.

Key Takeaways:

  • VDRL and RPR are non-treponemal tests that detect reagin antibodies, a general immune response to pallidum infection, not specific to the bacteria itself.
  • RPR is faster and better suited for individual sample testing because it does not require a microscope to interpret results.
  • VDRL is typically used in batch testing and is often used for large sample volumes, like in antenatal screenings.
  • Non-treponemal tests are most sensitive in the secondary stage, and less reliable in the late stages or for diagnosing congenital syphilis.

References:

  • Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidelines on syphilis diagnosis.
  • Current diagnostic strategies in syphilis: molecular and serological methods. J Clin Microbiol. 2022.
  • WHO diagnostic protocols for sexually transmitted infections.

questions.text: A forensic psychiatrist is evaluating a patient who shows a pronounced sexual arousal for partners with tattoos, piercings, and other forms of body modifications. This preference is referred to as?
questions.solution:
Stigmatophilia is a paraphilia characterized by a strong preference or sexual arousal from partners with body modifications such as tattoos, piercings, scars, or other marks.

Other examples of Sexual paraphilia include:

  • Piquerism: involves sexual arousal from stabbing or cutting the skin of another person (option A)
  • Hebephilia: involves a sexual preference for early adolescent children (option C)
  • Troilism: involves sexual arousal from watching one's partner engage in sexual activity with another person (option D)
  • Eonism/Transvestism: Sexual gratification is achieved by wearing the dress of the opposite sex.
  • Fetishism: Gets sexual gratification by merely seeing or feeling female body parts, certain articles belonging to a woman, such as a sari, footwear, stockings, undergarments, hankies, hairpins, 1 etc
  • Masochism: Sexual gratification is obtained by being tortured by the sex partner. (opposite of Sadism)
  • Sadism: Sexual gratification is achieved by inducing pain in the sex partner.
  • Voyeurism/Peeping Tom or Scotophilia: Sexual gratification by secretly watching others getting undressed, taking a bath, performing sexual intercourse, etc.
  • Nymphomania: A type of perversion of excessive sexual desire in a woman
  • Satyriasis: Excessive sexual desire, arousal, and drive in men.
  • Frotteurism: Gets sexual gratification by pressing/rubbing his genital part through the dresses worn, against the body parts of a female in front of him.
  • Undinism: Gets sexual gratification by watching the act of passing urine or defecating by a woman

questions.solution:
• A laryngocele is the dilatation of the saccule of the laryngeal ventricle and is unilateral in the vast majority of cases. Thus option A is not true.

Communication with the laryngeal ventricle is not always identified, and an extralaryngeal extension through the thyrohyoid membrane may or may not be present.

questions.text: Which of the following factors is most responsible for the production of aqueous humor in the eye?
questions.solution:
Normal Aqueous Humor

  • Properties: Transparent, colorless, low refractive index.
  • Formation: Continuously formed from plasma by ciliary epithelial cells.
  • Mechanism: Involves ultrafiltration, diffusion, and secretion. The secretory process accounts for ~95% of total aqueous production, powered by metabolic activity of the ciliary epithelium.
  • Composition: Contains water, sodium, ascorbic acid, and other substances secreted by the ciliary epithelium, along with plasma diffusible constituents. It has lower levels of most plasma constituents, except for those specifically secreted.
  • Blood-Aqueous Barrier: Tight junctions between non-pigmented epithelial cells form the blood-aqueous barrier, limiting entry of substances from blood into the aqueous humor.
  • Excess Lactic Acid: The aqueous humor has an excess of lactic acid due to lens metabolism.

choices.text: Man has high cardiac efficiency than child
Cardiac efficiency of both are same
Child has higher efficiency than man

questions.text: A 45-year-old average (body surface area 1.6 square meter) male has cardiac output of 6 liter per minute. A 6-year-old child has cardiac output of 3.5 liter per minute and body surface area is 0.8 square meters. Compare the cardiac efficiency between this man and child.
questions.solution:
• Cardiac output in any case is a good indicator of cardiac efficiency.
  • But to compare the cardiac efficiency in different age groups cardiac index is a better calculator for efficiency comparison.
  • Cardiac index can be measured by dividing cardiac output by body surface area for each individual.
  • If we measure the cardiac index in child it will be 4.75 liter/min/ square meter of BSA.
  • Cardiac index in 45-year-old is 3.75 liter/min/ square meter of BSA.

Option a: Incorrect, because the child has a higher cardiac index than the man.

Option b: Incorrect, because the cardiac efficiencies differ (child's is higher).

Option c: Correct, as the child's cardiac index is higher than the man's.

Option d: Incorrect, because the data allows a clear comparison of cardiac efficiency.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman reports watery vaginal discharge three weeks after TLH. Examination reveals pooling of fluid in the vagina. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Watery vaginal discharge post-TLH suggests a vesicovaginal fistula, a rare but significant complication. Diagnosis can be confirmed by cystoscopy or dye tests.

Option-wise Explanation:

  • A) Vesicovaginal fistula: Correct. Continuous watery vaginal discharge after TLH is highly suggestive of a vesicovaginal fistula (VVF), caused by unrecognized injury to the bladder during surgery. Pooling of fluid in the vagina and persistent discharge warrant diagnostic confirmation via cystoscopy or dye tests (e.g., methylene blue).
  • B) Vaginal cuff dehiscence: Vaginal cuff dehiscence typically presents with symptoms of acute pelvic pain, vaginal bleeding, or discharge, sometimes with evisceration of bowel contents. Watery discharge alone is less characteristic of this complication.
  • C) Ureterovaginal fistula: Ureterovaginal fistulas also cause watery vaginal discharge, but they are distinguished by intermittent discharge, positional changes in flow, and associated flank pain.
  • D) Cystitis: Cystitis (urinary tract infection) presents with dysuria, urgency, and frequency, rather than continuous watery discharge.

Reference: ACOG: Management of Complications in Minimally Invasive Gynecologic Surgery, 2021

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman diagnosed with Complete Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (CAIS) is seeking management options for her primary amenorrhea and concerns about infertility. Her karyotype is 46, XY, and she has absent menstruation with normal external female genitalia. What is the first line of management for her condition?
questions.solution:
• Gonadectomy is the first line of management in CAIS due to the increased risk of gonadal tumors in undescended testes (commonly found in CAIS patients). Testicular cancer risk is about 5-10% by the age of 50 years, making early gonadectomy a standard recommendation.
  • Estrogen replacement therapy (B) is necessary after gonadectomy to induce secondary sexual characteristics, but it is not the first-line treatment.
  • Hysterectomy (C) is unnecessary because the patient does not have a uterus or any functional reproductive organs.
  • Laparoscopy for testicular biopsy (D) is not required unless fertility preservation is being explored, and this is more relevant after gonadectomy.

questions.text: A dairy farmer presents with intermittent fever, night sweats, arthralgia, and fatigue. He reports handling livestock and consuming unpasteurized milk. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Brucellosis is caused by Brucella species, transmitted through contact with infected animals or their products like unpasteurized milk. It manifests as undulant fever (intermittent fever), arthralgia, and fatigue. Commonly associated with farmers, veterinarians, and dairy workers. Control involves pasteurization of milk and vaccination of cattle.

Diagnosis: ELISA, PCR, culture

questions.text: A 15 yr old boy came to OPD with yellowish discoloration of eyes. LFT reveals total bilirubin- 4mg/dL, direct bilirubin -3.6mg/dL, SGOT- 28U/L, SGPT- 30U/L, ALP- 80U/L. Liver biopsy shows the accumulation of dark, coarsely granular pigment in the lysosomes of centrilobular hepatocytes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

OPTION A- Dubin-Johnson Syndrome (DJS) This benign, relatively rare disorder is characterized by low-grade, predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Total bilirubin concentrations are typically between 34 and 85 μmol/L (2 and 5 mg/dL) but on occasion can be in the normal range or as high as 340-430 μmol/L (20-25 mg/dL).

A cardinal feature of DJS is the accumulation of dark, coarsely granular pigment in the lysosomes of centrilobular hepatocytes. As a result, the liver may be grossly black in appearance. This pigment is thought to be derived from epinephrine metabolites that are not excreted normally.

OPTION B- Rotor Syndrome (RS) This benign, autosomal recessive disorder is clinically similar to DJS, although it is seen even less frequently. A major phenotypic difference is that the liver in patients with RS has no increased pigmentation and appears totally normal.

OPTION C- CN-I is characterized by striking unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia of ∼340-765 μmol/L (20-45 mg/ dL) that appears in the neonatal period and persists for life.

CN-II - It differs from CN-I in several specific ways (1) although there is considerable overlap, average bilirubin concentrations are lower in CN-II; (2) accordingly, CN-II is only infrequently associated with kernicterus; (3) bile is deeply colored, and bilirubin glucuronides are present, with a striking, characteristic increase in the proportion of monoglucuronides; (4) UGT1A1 in liver is usually present at reduced levels (typically ≤10% of normal); and (5) while typically detected in infancy, hyperbilirubinemia was not recognized in some cases until later in life

OPTION D- This syndrome is characterized by mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, normal values for standard hepatic biochemical tests, and normal hepatic histology other than a modest increase of lipofuscin pigment in some patients. Serum bilirubin concentrations are most often <51 μmol/L (<3 mg/dL), although both higher and lower values are frequent.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Grossly black liver with dark granular pigment in the lysosomes of centrilobular hepatocytes in a case of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia is a specific finding for Dubin Johnson Syndrome.

questions.text: What is the maximum time duration for which a patient can be admitted under supported admission (Section 90) before a review is necessary?
questions.solution:
Under Section 90 of the MHCA 2017, supported admission can be extended to a maximum of 180 days after the initial 90-day period, provided that the concerned board reviews and approves the continued admission.

MHCA 2017

Independent Admission (Sec 86):

  • For patients with capacity to make treatment decisions.
  • Requires self-considered admission request and minimal support.

Admission of Minors (Sec 87):

  • Requires application by nominated representative.
  • Assessment by two psychiatrists or one psychiatrist and one medical practitioner.

Supported Admission for ≤ 30 Days (Sec 89):

  • Can be initiated by a mental health professional after evaluation.
  • For patients at risk to self/others or unable to care for themselves.
  • Requires assessment every 7 days for capacity.

Supported Admission for > 30 Days (Sec 90):

  • Requires assessment by two independent psychiatrists.
  • Review every 7 days and treatment consent provided by nominated representative.

Emergency Treatment (Sec 94):

  • Informed consent from nominated representative required.
  • Treatment limited to 72 hours.
  • No ECT in emergencies.

Patient Rights:

  • Right to discharge request (independent patient).
  • Minor patients acquire adult rights when they turn 18.

Board Review:

  • Board reviews supported admissions within 21 days.
  • Extensions possible up to 180 days.

Discharge and Treatment Planning:

  • Discharge may be delayed by psychiatric evaluation.
  • Supported admissions need continuous review by boards.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with episodic headache, sweating, and palpitations. Which test is most specific for diagnosing pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
OPTION A - Serum cortisol levels are not relevant in diagnosing pheochromocytoma.

OPTION B - Urinary free catecholamines are sensitive but less specific compared to plasma metanephrines.

OPTION C - Hypokalemia is associated with primary hyperaldosteronism, not pheochromocytoma.

OPTION D - Plasma metanephrines are the most specific and sensitive diagnostic test for pheochromocytoma.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

Pheochromocytoma diagnosis relies on biochemical testing, with plasma metanephrines being the gold standard.

questions.text: What does the abbreviation MIDCAB stand for in cardiac surgery?
questions.solution:
Minimally invasive direct coronary artery bypass (MIDCAB) grafting is performed through a small incision and avoids the invasive aspects of conventional CABG.

Key TakeAway Point:

Through an anterior submammary incision, the LIMA can be dissected using a thoracoscope and grafted to the LAD.

More lateral incisions allow access to other coronary vessels, including branches of the circumflex artery. Although not yet evidence-based, one approach is to combine MIDCAB (typically LIMA to LAD) with PCI to other less accessible coronary arteries ('hybrid' coronary revascularization).

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a clinical feature of ankylosing spondylitis?
questions.solution:
OPTION A - Low back pain that improves with activity is a hallmark of ankylosing spondylitis.

OPTION B - Bamboo spine is a radiological finding due to spinal fusion seen in ankylosing spondylitis.

OPTION C - Dactylitis, or "sausage digits," may occur due to enthesitis.

OPTION D - Ulnar deviation is characteristic of rheumatoid arthritis, not ankylosing spondylitis.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

  2. Radiological findings include sacroiliitis and syndesmophytes.
  3. First-line treatment includes NSAIDs and physiotherapy.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features is not typically seen in Korsakoff's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Option A: Severe anterograde amnesia:

Incorrect. Severe anterograde memory loss is a hallmark of Korsakoff's syndrome. Patients have difficulty forming new memories and remembering recent events, while older memories are generally better preserved.

Option B: Spontaneous confabulation:

Incorrect. Confabulation is a common symptom in Korsakoff's syndrome. It can be spontaneous (without provocation) or provoked (triggered by questions), with spontaneous confabulations often disappearing in the early stages of the disorder.

Option C: Preserved procedural memory:

Incorrect. Procedural memory, which involves skills and habits, is generally preserved in Korsakoff's syndrome. The primary cognitive dysfunction affects declarative memory (facts and events), not procedural memory.

Option D: Significant motor weakness and ataxia:

Correct. While Korsakoff's syndrome primarily affects memory and cognition, it does not typically involve significant motor weakness or ataxia. These symptoms are more commonly seen in other neurological conditions, such as cerebellar disorders, not in Korsakoff's syndrome.

KORSAKOFF'S SYNDROME

Definition:

  • Korsakoff's syndrome is characterized by memory and learning deficits disproportionate to other cognitive functions in an otherwise alert and responsive patient.
  • Classified as an alcohol-induced amnestic disorder (ICD-10) and alcohol-induced major neurocognitive disorder (DSM-5).

Epidemiology:

  • Incidence of approximately 0.5 per 10,000 in older western studies.
  • No data from Indian studies.

Aetiology:

  • Caused by severe thiamine deficiency, often following untreated or partially treated conditions.
  • Common in alcoholics; also seen in puerperal sepsis, gastric carcinoma, intractable vomiting, and severe dietary deficiency.

Neuropathology:

  • Involves neuronal loss, micro-hemorrhages, and gliosis in paraventricular and periaqueductal grey matter.
  • Mammillary bodies and anterior thalamic nuclei are critically affected for memory loss.

Effect of Thiamine Depletion:

  • Thiamine is essential for various biochemical processes in the brain, including carbohydrate metabolism, lipid metabolism, and neurotransmitter production.
  • Thiamine deficiency leads to damage in astrocytes and impaired cellular energy metabolism.

Neuroimaging Findings:

  • MRI shows atrophy in mammillary bodies, thalamus, and other structures, with ventricular expansion.

Clinical Features:

  • Memory dysfunction: Anterograde memory most severely affected, with recent memories more impaired than older ones.
  • Executive dysfunction: Affects cognitive processes like planning and working memory.
  • Confabulation: Can be provoked (plausible) or spontaneous (grandiose).
  • Apathy and emotional disturbances: Often irritability, euphoria, and unstable emotions.

Course of Illness:

  • 25% of patients show complete improvement, 50% show partial recovery, and the rest show no improvement.

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical diagnosis based on memory deficits with intact intelligence.
  • No specific lab tests; diagnostic workup may include blood tests, toxicology, lumbar puncture, and brain imaging.

Treatment:

  • Early intervention with thiamine supplementation to prevent progression.
  • No effective pharmacological treatment for established KS.
  • Rehabilitation, memory compensation techniques, and errorless learning are helpful

questions.text: EMLA cream local numbing cream is sometimes applied to the skin before attempting an intravenous access in pediatric patients. Which of the following local anesthetics is combined to produce this cream?
questions.solution:
• EMLA (Eutectic Mixture of Local Anesthetics) cream was formulated to overcome the obstacles presented by intact skin. It consists of a mixture of lidocaine and prilocaine bases in an emulsion.
  • Depth of analgesia (usually <0.5 cm), duration of action (usually <2 h), and amount of drug absorbed depend on application time, dermal blood flow, and total dose administered.
  • Typically, 1 to 2 g of cream is applied per 10-cm2 area of skin. Dermal analgesia sufficient for inserting an intravenous catheter requires about 1 h under an occlusive dressing.

questions.text: Which of the following fetal complications is most commonly associated with GDM?
questions.solution:
GDM can lead to polyhydramnios due to fetal hyperglycemia causing osmotic diuresis.

Option-wise Explanation:

A) Microcephaly:

  • Microcephaly is not commonly associated with GDM.
  • It is more frequently linked to congenital infections (e.g., TORCH infections) or genetic disorders.

B) Polyhydramnios (Correct Answer):

  • GDM often leads to fetal hyperglycemia, which causes osmotic diuresis in the fetus, leading to an increase in amniotic fluid volume (polyhydramnios).
  • Polyhydramnios is one of the most common fetal complications of GDM.

C) Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR):

  • IUGR is less common in GDM unless there is coexisting vascular compromise (e.g., pregestational diabetes with vasculopathy).
  • More often, GDM results in macrosomia rather than IUGR.

D) Oligohydramnios:

  • Oligohydramnios is typically associated with placental insufficiency, post-term pregnancy, or fetal anomalies affecting the urinary system.
  • It is not a common complication of GDM.

questions.text: Which of the following infections requires male partner treatment?
questions.solution:
• Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. It is essential to treat all sexual partners to prevent reinfection and further spread of the disease.

Option A. Candida: This fungal infection can occur in individuals due to factors like diabetes or immunocompromised states, and does not typically necessitate partner treatment.

Option B. Bacterial vaginosis: This condition is not classified as an STI and does not require treatment of male partners.

Option D. Herpes: While herpes is a recurrent viral infection, it does not always require partner treatment, as recurrences can occur without new exposure.

Key Takeaways:

  • Trichomoniasis requires treatment for both partners to effectively manage and eliminate the infection.
  • Understanding the nature of each infection is crucial for appropriate management and prevention strategies.

questions.text: Which of the following is a typical finding in vascular dementia (Binswanger's disease)?
questions.solution:
Option A is incorrect because aphasia and agnosia are more characteristic of cortical dementias.

Option B is incorrect as subcortical motor symptoms are more typical of Parkinson’s or Huntington's diseases.

Option C is correct. Vascular dementia, including Binswanger’s disease, typically shows memory deficits, and recall can be improved with cues.

Option D is more indicative of pseudodementia or subcortical dementia with fluctuating cognitive performance.


Common Causes of Dementia:

  • Parenchymatous Brain Disease: Alzheimer's, Huntington’s.
  • Vascular Dementia: Multi-infarct dementia.
  • Toxic: Alcohol, drugs, heavy metals.
  • Metabolic: Wilson’s disease, liver encephalopathy.
  • Endocrine: Thyroid, adrenal dysfunction.
  • Deficiency: Vitamin deficiencies (e.g., B12, thiamine).
  • Infections: HIV, Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease.
  • Neoplastic: Brain tumors.
  • Traumatic: Head injury, chronic subdural hematoma.
  • Hydrocephalic: Normal pressure hydrocephalus.

questions.text: Young female patient of 7 years presents with dystonia, weakness and mild behavioural symptoms, recently complaints change of her handwriting. MRI brain was done shown below: Which of the following sign is depicted in given MRI images?
questions.solution:
CNS MANIFESTATION OF WILSON DISEASE:

T2/FLAIR:

abnormal hyperintensity in the putamina is the most common.

common T2 signal abnormality can include the caudate nuclei, globus pallidi, ventrolateral thalami, and the deep Gray nuclei in the midbrain.

The pons and cerebellum are less commonly involved

In the cerebral hemispheres, symmetric, multifocal, leukoencephalopathy may uncommonly (~25%) be seen, with a frontal predominance

Radiological signs in Wilsons disease:

face of the giant panda sign: involvement of the midbrain tegmentum

face of the miniature (cub) panda sign: involvement of the pontine tegmentum

double panda sign: combination of the face of the giant panda sign and face of the miniature (cub) panda sign

bright claustrum sign: hyperintensity of the claustrum

split thalamus sign: within thalamic hyperintensity, a curvilinear hyperintensity is more prominently noted between medial and lateral groups of nuclei, seen to be 'splitting' the thalamus

whorl sign: concentric hyperintensities within the putamina

T1 images: hepatic dysfunction, these areas show increased T1 signal 2,4,9, especially in the globus pallidi, similar to that seen in hepatocerebral degenration attributed to manganese deposition

GRE/SWI: there may be blooming artifact in similar regions involved in abnormal T2 signal, including the putamina (most common), caudate nuclei, ventrolateral thalami, and dentate nuclei.

Medusa head sign - Developmental venous anomaly

Salt and pepper sign - Glomus tumor

Durl tail sign - seen in meningioma

questions.text: The "big four" NCDs (cardiovascular diseases, cancers, chronic respiratory diseases, and diabetes) account for what percentage of premature NCD deaths?
questions.solution:
Key facts

  • Noncommunicable diseases (NCDs) kill 41 million people each year, equivalent to 74% of all deaths globally.
  • Each year, 17 million people die from a NCD before age 70; 86% of these premature deaths occur in low- and middle-income countries.
  • Of all NCD deaths, 77% are in low- and middle-income countries.
  • Cardiovascular diseases account for most NCD deaths, or 17.9 million people annually, followed by cancers (9.3 million), chronic respiratory diseases (4.1 million), and diabetes (2.0 million including kidney disease deaths caused by diabetes).
  • These four groups of diseases account for over 80% of all premature NCD deaths.
  • Tobacco use, physical inactivity, the harmful use of alcohol, unhealthy diets and air pollution all increase the risk of dying from an NCD.
  • Detection, screening and treatment of NCDs, as well as palliative care, are key components of the response to NCDs.

Reference:- World Health Organization: WHO. Noncommunicable diseases [Internet]. 2023. Available from: https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/noncommunicable-diseases

questions.text: A 26-year-old male is brought to emergency with acute cocaine toxicity. Which of the following are features of cocaine intoxication except?
questions.solution:
OPTION A- Cocaine overdose presents as sympathetic nervous system overactivity not CNS depression.

OPTION B & C- Overdose presents as sympathetic nervous system overactivity with psychomotor agitation, hypertension, tachycardia, headache, and mydriasis, and can lead to convulsions, cerebral hemorrhage or infarction, cardiac arrhythmias or ischemia, respiratory failure, or rhabdomyolysis.

OPTION D- Peripheral effects may include tremor, diaphoresis, hypertonia, tachypnea, hyperreflexia, and hyperthermia.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Cocaine overdose is a medical emergency; treatment is largely symptomatic and should occur in an intensive care or telemetry unit.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male with a history of arthritis treated with NSAIDs presents with acute abdominal pain and pneumoperitoneum. His symptoms began 6 hours ago. After receiving 1 liter of normal saline, his vital signs have stabilized. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Option D:

The preferred treatment for perforated duodenal ulcers is prompt surgery after resuscitation. Nonoperative management is only appropriate for select cases, such as old, contained perforations or terminally ill patients unable to tolerate surgery.

Option A:

The diagnosis of perforation is often clinical and confirmed radiographically (pneumoperitoneum). However, when clinical suspicion is high and radiographic findings support it, immediate surgery is preferred over further diagnostic imaging.

Option B:

The management of perforated ulcers focuses on resuscitation and surgical repair, not endoscopy, which may be performed later in stable patients to assess ulcer healing or H. pylori status.

Option C:

While antisecretory therapy and antibiotics are critical components of postoperative care and H. pylori eradication, they do not replace the need for immediate surgical repair in acute perforations.

Key Takeaway Point:

  • Patients who have had one perforation may have another.
  • Therefore, they should be managed aggressively to ensure this does not happen. Lifelong treatment with PPIs is a reasonable option, especially for those who have to continue with NSAID treatment.

questions.text: Which fetal vessel carries the highest oxygen concentration?
questions.solution:
A. Umbilical artery:

  • The umbilical artery carries deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta for oxygen exchange.
  • Oxygen concentration is relatively low.

B. Umbilical vein (Correct Answer):

  • The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus.
  • This vessel has the highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation, delivering oxygen and nutrients to the fetus.

C. Ductus arteriosus:

  • The ductus arteriosus connects the pulmonary artery to the descending aorta, shunting blood away from the lungs.
  • Blood in this vessel is mixed, with a lower oxygen concentration than the umbilical vein.

D. Pulmonary artery:

  • In the fetus, the pulmonary artery carries blood from the right ventricle to the lungs, but due to the shunting of blood through the ductus arteriosus, the oxygen concentration remains low.

Reference: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG). Guidelines on Fetal Physiology and Development.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about osteoid osteoma?
questions.solution:
Osteoid Osteoma

Definition

  • Osteoid osteoma is the most common true benign tumor of bone.
  • Pathologically, it consists of a nidus of tangled arrays of partially mineralized osteoid trabeculae surrounded by dense sclerotic bone.

Clinical Presentation

  • Age Group: Commonly occurs between 5 to 25 years of age.
  • Commonly Affected Bones:
    • Bones of the lower extremity, with the tibia being the most frequently involved.
    • Typically located in the diaphysis of long bones.
    • Posterior elements of the vertebrae are also common sites.
  • Symptoms:
    • Nagging pain, worse at night, relieved by salicylates (due to prostaglandin production by the tumor).
    • Minimal or no clinical signs, except:
      • Mild tenderness at the lesion site.
      • A palpable swelling if the lesion is superficial.

Diagnosis

  • X-ray Findings:
    • The tumor appears as a zone of sclerosis surrounding a radiolucent nidus, usually less than 1 cm in size.
    • In cases where the nidus is obscured by extensive sclerosis, a CT scan may be required for detection.

Treatment

  • Surgical Management:
    • Complete excision of the nidus along with the surrounding sclerotic bone.
  • Prognosis:
    • Prognosis is excellent.
    • Osteoid osteoma is not a pre-malignant condition.
