• Nikshay:- TB surveillance using care based, web-based IT system. The software was launched in May 2012 and has following functional components :- master management, user details, TB patient registration and details of diagnosis, DOTS provider, HIV status, follow up, contact tracing, outcomes etc, details of solid and liquid culture and DST, LPA, CBNAAT details, DR-TB patient registration with details, referral and transfer of patients, private health facility registration and TB notification, mobile application for TB notification, SMS alerts to patients on registration, SMS alerts to programme officers, automated periodic reports.
  • Nishchay:- Nishchay rapid in-vitro diagnostics kit, for the detection of pregnancy, is manufactured for the government of India's maternal and child health programme.
  • Nikshay poshan Abhiyan:- it is a government scheme in India that was announced by Prime Minister Narendra Modi in April of 2018 with the aim of helping tuberculosis patient. The scheme is working towards betterment of patients with tuberculosis (TB) by providing them with 500 rupees per month to buy food. If the patient is tribal with drug resistant tuberculosis government provide 750 rupees per month.
  • 99 DOTS:- it is low-cost strategy for monitoring and improving medication adherence. Under this patient send a free call each time they take their medication, so that providers can monitor adherence calls. Patients' medication is packaged in custom secondary envelops with add dosage instruction, and a series of hidden numbers behind the pills. Each time a patient takes a dose of medication, a hidden number is revealed which is unpredictable to the patient. The revealed number completes a phone number, where the first part of the number is printed on the front side of the envelope. The patient then makes a free call to the completed phone number.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest sign of fat embolism syndrome?
questions.solution:
OPTION A - Petechial rash is a later sign and is not present in all cases.

OPTION B - Hypoxemia is often the earliest clinical manifestation due to pulmonary microvascular occlusion.

OPTION C - Confusion and altered mental status may occur later as a result of cerebral embolism or hypoxemia.

OPTION D - Tachycardia is a non-specific finding.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

Fat embolism syndrome typically presents with the triad of hypoxemia, neurologic changes, and petechial rash, with hypoxemia often being the earliest sign.

questions.text: A young male presented to the surgical OPD with the following finding as shown in the image. Identify the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Option C: MEN 2B - MEN 2B is also caused by RET mutations, half de novo.

A variant of MEN 2B is characterized by an aggressive and early-onset form of MTC (100%), PPGL (59%), marfanoid habitus, and ganglioneuromatosis of the oral mucosa and gut.

Option A:


Image showing geographic tongue ( Source: Cleveland Clinic)

Option B: MEN 2A: It is an autosomal dominant condition caused by germline mutations in RET, which encodes a transmembrane tyrosine kinase receptor (TKR) that activates pathways involved in proliferation, survival, migration, and angiogenesis.

MEN 2A - Medullary thyroid carcinoma, Primary hyperparathyroidism, Phaeochromocytoma

Option D: MEN 4 - is thought to be due to mutations in CDNK1B.

Key Take Away Point:

MEN 1 is an autosomal dominant inherited disorder. It was originally called Wermer's syndrome. It presents as PHPT, Pancreatic islet cell tumors, and Pituitary tumors. MEN 1 is also associated with meningiomas and facial angiofibroma.

questions.text: Ultrasound image of 9-year-old male child is given below which present with surgical OPD with chief complaint of abdominal pain and occasional diarrhoea. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Given ultrasound image shows classic target sign which is diagnostic of intussusception.

Ultrasound signs of intussusception include:

  • Target sign (also known as the doughnut sign)
  • Pseudo kidney sign ( also seen in pathological wall thickening)
  • Absent blood flow in intussusceptum (Contraindication to enema reduction)
  • Free fluid within the intusussceptum
  • A lead point within the intussusceptum mass e.g. lymph node - Most common Children.

A small bony fragment at the base of the second metatarsal

questions.text: What does the "Fleck Sign" indicate in the context of a Lisfranc injury?
questions.solution:
Historical Background

The Tarso-Metatarsal (TMT) joint, also known as the Lisfranc joint, owes its name to Jacques L. Lisfranc, a French gynecologist and Napoleonic surgeon. He was the first to describe an amputation technique through the TMT joint line and the plantar ligamentous connections between the first and second TMT joints.

While Lisfranc detailed the anatomy and surgical relevance of this region, acute injuries such as fracture-dislocations of the TMT joint were not described by him. Nevertheless, injuries at the TMT joint are named "Lisfranc injuries" due to their anatomical location.

Clinical Overview

  • Prevalence: Acute Lisfranc injuries are rare, accounting for only 0.1% to 0.4% of all fractures and dislocations.
  • Diagnostic Challenges: Despite advancements in diagnostic techniques, Lisfranc injuries are frequently missed or overlooked, emphasizing the need for careful assessment.

Radiographic Sign: The Fleck Sign

  • Definition: The "Fleck Sign" refers to an avulsion fracture of the base of the second metatarsal or medial cuneiform.
  • Significance: It is pathognomonic for a Lisfranc injury and indicates a bony fragment from the Lisfranc ligament.
  • Appearance: The Fleck Sign is typically seen on radiographs as a small bony fragment at the base of the second metatarsal, confirming the diagnosis of a Lisfranc injury.

questions.text: A health freak mother is giving her child Vitamin D since long time without any medical consultation. You suspect the child having hypervitaminosis D. Which of the following is not the feature?
questions.solution:
• Symptoms associated with hypervitaminosis D are:
    • Anorexia, weight loss, weakness, fatigue, disorientation, vomiting, dehydration, polyuria, constipation and bone pain.
  • Lab findings include: hypercalcemia, hypercalciuria, hematuria and albuminuria.
  • Hyponatremia is associated with vitamin D deficiency.

questions.text: A 34 year old male presented with skin lesion over lower back, scalp. On eliciting clinical test, there was pinpoint bleeding. This sign is seen in?
questions.solution:
When scales of psoriasis are scraped, characteristic coherence of silvery scale like a candle wax are seen (Grattage test).

When scales are completely scraped off, basement membrane is exposed as seen as moist red surface( membrane of Bulkeley) through which dilated capillaries at the top of elongated dermal papillae are torn, leading to multiple bleeding points.This sign is known as Auspitz sign.

Auspitz sign seen in- Psoriasis vulgaris, Darier disease, Actinic keratosis

Not seen in - Inverse psoriasis, pustular psoriasis, guttate psoriasis, erythrodermic psoriasis (Option C)

Option A- Nikolsky sign is seen in pemphigus vulgaris

Option D- Tin tack sign is seen in DLE (Discoid lupus erythematosus).

questions.text: A patient with cervical cancer is undergoing concurrent chemoradiation therapy. What is the primary mechanism of action of cisplatin in this treatment?
questions.solution:
Cisplatin is a platinum-based chemotherapeutic agent that works primarily by binding to DNA and forming cross-links between DNA strands. This binding prevents proper DNA replication and transcription, ultimately leading to DNA damage that cannot be repaired effectively. As a result, cancer cells undergo apoptosis (programmed cell death), and the cell's ability to repair radiation-induced DNA damage is compromised. This makes cisplatin particularly effective when used in combination with radiation therapy in the treatment of cervical cancer.

  • Option A: Inhibition of microtubule formation is the mechanism of action of taxanes like paclitaxel, not cisplatin.
  • Option C: Inhibition of folate metabolism is the mechanism of action of methotrexate, not cisplatin.
  • Option D: Cisplatin does not affect the estrogen receptor, which is targeted by agents like tamoxifen.

Reference: American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) Guidelines for Cervical Cancer Treatment

choices.text: Atypical giant cells and non-septate hyphae
Sclerotic bodies with a "copper penny" appearance
Hyaline, septate hyphae with acute-angle branching

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with a chronic, verrucous skin lesion on the leg. Histopathological examination of the biopsy reveals fungal elements that appear as thick-walled, brownish bodies within a background of chronic granulomatous inflammation. Which of the following findings is most indicative of chromoblastomycosis?
questions.solution:
Sclerotic bodies with a "copper penny" appearance: These are hallmark features of chromoblastomycosis. They are pigmented, thick-walled fungal cells and are critical for diagnosis.

Option A: Acanthosis and koilocytic changes: These are associated with viral infections like HPV, leading to warts and condylomas, not chromoblastomycosis.

Option B: Atypical giant cells and non-septate hyphae: These features are more indicative of infections like mucormycosis or histoplasmosis, which are not characteristic of chromoblastomycosis.

OptionD: Hyaline, septate hyphae with acute-angle branching: This description is characteristic of Aspergillus species, not chromoblastomycosis.

Key takeaway-

Chromoblastomycosis

Deep fungal infection with Chronic verrucous fungating lesion

MC site- trauma prone site- Foot

Hallmark features- Sclerotic bodies with a "copper penny" appearance.

questions.text: Symptomatic neonatal CNS involvement is most commonly seen in which group of congenital intrauterine infections?
questions.solution:
• CNS manifestation are present in all TORCH infections. They develop these symptoms in late infancy and not in neonatal age.
  • Herpes and Rubella infections have more chances of having CNS manifestations in neonatal period compared to other TORCH infections.

questions.text: A 70 year old male patient presented with pruritus, eczema and urticarial rashes. Histopathological examination reveals subepidermal blister and Direct Immunofluorescence of the lesions showed Linear C3 and IgG on Basement membrane. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Bullous pemphigoid

  • Age group: Elderly people
  • Clinical presentation: Starts with pruritus and urticated and erythematous lesions. Later, tense blisters are characteristic both on erythematous and on normal skin.
  • Mucosal : In a minority of patients and is not predominant.
  • Histopathology: subepidermal splitting.
  • Autoantibodies: Chiefly IgG, recognize two proteins of the DEJ, BP180 (type XVII collagen) and BP230.
  • DIF: linear binding of immunoglobulin G (IgG) at the dermal-epidermal junction.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with primary infertility undergoes hysteroscopy, which reveals an arcuate uterus. What is the next step in her management?
questions.solution:
An arcuate uterus is a congenital uterine anomaly that typically has no significant impact on fertility or pregnancy outcomes. Expectant management is usually appropriate for women with this condition unless there is a history of recurrent miscarriage or other complications.

Option-wise Explanation:

A) Laparoscopic myomectomy:

This procedure is used to remove fibroids and is not indicated for an arcuate uterus.

B) Expectant management (Correct):

The arcuate uterus does not usually require surgical correction unless it is associated with adverse reproductive outcomes, which is rare.

C) Hysteroscopic septoplasty:

This procedure is reserved for a septate uterus, which is associated with recurrent pregnancy loss or infertility. An arcuate uterus does not meet the criteria for this intervention.

D) In-vitro fertilization (IVF):

IVF may be considered for other causes of infertility but is not specifically required for an arcuate uterus.

Topic: Hysteroscopy & Infertility

Reference: ASRM Practice Guidelines on Uterine Evaluation in Infertility, 2023.

questions.text: The patient is experiencing no significant gastrointestinal discomfort, but he is worried about the long-term risks of his TB medication. Which drug in his regimen is most likely to cause peripheral neuropathy if not monitored properly?
questions.solution:
• Rifampicin:- the toxic effects include hepatotoxicity, gastritis, influenza like illness, purpura, thrombocytopenia, and nephrotoxicity. The patient should be told that the drug will turn the urine red, this can be used as test of compliance.
  • Isoniazid:- patient may experience gastrointestinal irritation, peripheral neuropathy, blood dyscrasias, hyperglycaemia and liver damage.
  • Ethambutol:- it is a bacteriostatic drug and is used in combination to prevent the emergence of resistance to other drugs. It is given orally. Its major side effect is retrobulbar neuritis, this however does not occur at the usual dosage.
  • Pyrazinamide:- complications include hepatotoxicity and hyperuricaemia. Pyrazinamide achieves high levels in CSF and is therefore recommended in tuberculous meningitis.

choices.text: Bedside measurement to assess volume status
Internal jugular vein is preferred over external jugular vein
Kussmaul's sign is defined by either a rise or a lack of fall of the JVP with inspiration
c wave represents right atrial presystolic contraction

questions.text: True regarding Jugular venous pressure except?
questions.solution:
OPTION A- The JVP is the single most important bedside measurement from which to estimate the volume status.

OPTION B- The internal jugular vein is preferred because the external jugular vein is valved and not directly in line with the superior vena cava and right atrium.

OPTION C- Kussmaul's sign is defined by either a rise or a lack of fall of the JVP with inspiration and is classically associated with constrictive pericarditis, although it has been reported in patients with restrictive cardiomyopathy, massive pulmonary embolism, right ventricular infarction, and advanced left ventricular (LV) systolic heart failure.

OPTION D- a wave represents right atrial presystolic contraction and occurs just after the electrocardiographic P wave and just before the first heart sound (I)

KEY TAKEAWAYS-

  • The a wave reflects right atrial presystolic contraction and occurs just after the electrocardiographic P wave, preceding the first heart sound (S1). A prominent a wave is seen in patients with reduced right ventricular compliance; a cannon a wave occurs with atrioventricular (AV) dissociation and right atrial contraction against a closed tricuspid valve. A wave is not present with atrial fibrillation.
  • The x descent defines the fall in right atrial pressure after inscription of a wave.
  • The c wave, which occurs as the closed tricuspid valve is pushed into the right atrium during early ventricular systole, interrupts this x descent and is followed by a further descent.
  • The v wave represents atrial filling (atrial diastole) and occurs during ventricular systole. The height of the v wave is determined by right atrial compliance as well as the volume of blood returning to the right atrium either antegrade from the cavae or retrograde through an incompetent tricuspid valve.
  • The y descent, which follows the peak of the v wave, can become prolonged or blunted with obstruction to right ventricular inflow, as may occur with tricuspid stenosis or pericardial tamponade.

choices.text: Surgical procedures designed to improve absorptive capacity have shown some promise in managing adults but not in children
Short bowel syndrome usually appears when there is less than 200 cm of small bowel
All patients with less than 100 cm of small intestine ending in a stoma will require long-term parenteral nutrition
The mainstay of treatment for short bowel syndrome remains home parenteral nutrition (HPN).

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding short bowel syndrome?
questions.solution:
Option A: Surgical procedures designed to improve the surface area or reduce the speed of transit of the remaining small intestine (and thus improve absorptive capacity) have shown some promise in children, but their place in managing adults with established short bowel syndrome currently remains unclear.

Option B: Features of short bowel syndrome usually appear when there is less than 200 cm of small bowel, the length and nature of the remaining intestine are also important.

Option C: Some (but not all) patients with 50-100 cm of small intestine and an intact colon will have intestinal failure, as will almost all patients with 50 cm or less of jejunum anastomosed to an intact colon. In contrast, most patients with less than 200 cm and virtually all with less than 100 cm of small intestine ending in a stoma will have intestinal failure and will require long-term parenteral nutrition.

Option D: Although there has also been interest in the use of drugs to promote intestinal adaptation, such as growth hormone, glutamine, and, most recently, glucagon-like peptide 2 agonists, the mainstay of treatment for short bowel syndrome remains home parenteral nutrition (HPN).

KeyTakeAwayMessage:

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with irregular vaginal bleeding and excessive nausea and vomiting for the past month. She is 10 weeks pregnant according to her last menstrual period. Pelvic ultrasound reveals a "snowstorm" pattern with no identifiable fetus. Serum beta-hCG levels are markedly elevated for gestational age. What is the definitive diagnostic tool for confirming gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD)?
questions.solution:
A) Serum beta-hCG levels:

  • Elevated beta-hCG levels strongly suggest GTD, but they are not definitive for diagnosing the type or confirming GTD. They are primarily used for screening and follow-up.

B) Pelvic ultrasound:

  • A "snowstorm" pattern on ultrasound is highly suggestive of GTD, particularly a complete hydatidiform mole. However, ultrasound cannot confirm the type of trophoblastic proliferation.

C) Histopathological examination of uterine contents (Correct Answer):

  • This is the gold standard for diagnosing GTD.
  • It allows confirmation of the type of trophoblastic proliferation (e.g., complete mole, partial mole, or malignant GTD).

D) MRI of the pelvis:

  • MRI can evaluate the extent of GTD, especially in suspected invasive or metastatic cases, but it is not used for definitive diagnosis.

Reference: FIGO Oncology Committee. Gestational Trophoblastic Disease Guidelines, 2015.

questions.text: A 44-year-old female presented to the vascular clinic with dull aching pain in the lower limb. She is found to have the following clinical picture. What is the clinical classification?
questions.solution:
The image shown here is Corona phlebectatica


Key Take home message:

Corona phlebectatica (malleolar fare): a fan-shaped pattern of telangiectasia on the ankle or foot. This is an early sign of advanced venous disease.

questions.text: A woman at 32 weeks gestation presents with a sudden onset of abdominal pain, uterine tenderness, and vaginal bleeding. On examination, the uterus is firm and tender. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Placental abruption occurs when the placenta prematurely detaches from the uterine wall, leading to painful bleeding and uterine tenderness. The condition can cause fetal distress and requires prompt management.

Explanation:

A) Placenta previa:

  • Placenta previa occurs when the placenta is abnormally located in the lower part of the uterus, covering or being close to the cervix.
  • It typically presents with painless vaginal bleeding, especially in the second or third trimester, and is not typically associated with uterine tenderness or abdominal pain.
  • Firm uterine tone and tenderness are not characteristic of placenta previa, making this diagnosis less likely in this case.

B) Placental abruption (Correct Answer):

  • Placental abruption is the most likely diagnosis in this case, given the combination of sudden onset of abdominal pain, uterine tenderness, and vaginal bleeding.
  • This condition occurs when the placenta prematurely detaches from the uterine wall, either partially or completely, which leads to bleeding, uterine tenderness, and abdominal pain.
  • The uterus is often firm to palpation, and this is a medical emergency that can result in significant maternal and fetal complications, such as fetal distress, preterm birth, or maternal hemorrhage.
  • Placental abruption requires immediate evaluation and management, including stabilization, monitoring, and sometimes early delivery depending on the severity.

C) Uterine rupture:

  • Uterine rupture is a rare but serious complication that can occur in labor, especially in women with previous cesarean sections or uterine scars.
  • It typically presents with severe abdominal pain, but it is more likely to cause hypovolemic shock, loss of fetal heart tones, and cessation of uterine contractions.
  • The patient would typically be in active labor or have risk factors like a previous uterine scar, making uterine rupture less likely in this case, as no clear labor or scar history is given.

D) Preterm labor:

  • Preterm labor is associated with uterine contractions and cervical changes, but it does not usually present with vaginal bleeding or abdominal tenderness as a primary symptom.
  • In preterm labor, contractions are typically regular, and the cervix may be dilating, but the patient usually does not present with a firm or tender uterus as seen in placental abruption.

questions.text: 134. A 55-year-old male with a history of diabetes presents with fatigue, anorexia, hyperpigmentation of the skin, and hyponatremia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
OPTION A - Addison's disease (primary adrenal insufficiency) is characterized by fatigue, hyperpigmentation, hypotension, and electrolyte disturbances like hyponatremia and hyperkalemia.

OPTION B - Cushing's syndrome causes central obesity, striae, and hyperglycemia, which do not fit this clinical presentation.

OPTION C - Hyperaldosteronism presents with hypertension and hypokalemia rather than hyperpigmentation and hyponatremia.

OPTION D - Pheochromocytoma causes episodic hypertension, headache, and palpitations.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

  1. Addison's disease results from autoimmune destruction of the adrenal cortex in most cases.
  2. ACTH stimulation test is the gold standard for diagnosis.
  3. Management includes glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid replacement therapy.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with her fourth episode of dizziness, sweating, and fatigue. Her blood glucose level is recorded at 40 mg/dL, and her symptoms improve rapidly after glucose administration. Similar episodes occurred in the past, with glucose levels of 37 and 43 mg/dL, respectively, each resolving with glucose treatment. The hospitalist refers her for further evaluation due to suspicion of insulinoma. What is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
Option C: The fasting test is the gold standard for diagnosing insulinoma. It measures glucose, insulin, and C-peptide levels during fasting to confirm insulinoma.

Option A: Proinsulin is often elevated in insulinoma, but it's not the first diagnostic test.

Option B: The OGTT is used for diabetes diagnosis, not insulinoma.

Option D: C-peptide levels are elevated in insulinoma but are part of the supervised fasting test. It is not the first test to do by itself.

KeyTakeHomeMessage:

The cornerstone of diagnosis remains Whipple's triad:

  • symptoms induced by fasting;
  • hypoglycemia at the time of symptoms;
  • symptoms relieved by administration of glucose.

The key test is a 72-hour fast looking for documented endogenous hyperinsulinism associated with symptoms and signs of low plasma glucose (<3.0 mmol/L), elevated insulin, and high C-peptide.

If the test is negative and the suspicion of insulinoma is high, a prolonged oral glucose tolerance test is done.

questions.text: What is the initial treatment of choice for an acute gout attack?
questions.solution:
OPTION A - Allopurinol is used for long-term urate-lowering therapy, not acute attacks.

OPTION B - Febuxostat, like allopurinol, is for chronic urate management and is not suitable for acute attacks.

OPTION C - Colchicine effectively reduces inflammation during acute gout attacks. It is most effective when started within the first 24 hours of symptom onset.

OPTION D - Probenecid is a uricosuric agent and not recommended for acute gout.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

  1. Acute gout is best managed with NSAIDs, colchicine, or corticosteroids.
  2. Avoid urate-lowering therapy initiation during an acute attack as it may exacerbate symptoms.
  3. Lifestyle modifications (e.g., reduced purine intake) complement pharmacologic therapy.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents with fluctuating jaundice, pruritus, and fatigue. Liver function tests show cholestasis. Abdominal ultrasound reveals no evidence of gallstones or bile duct dilation. What is the next best diagnostic test to perform?
questions.solution:
Concept: The clinical scenario suggests primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) due to symptoms like fluctuating jaundice, pruritus, and cholestasis, with no gallstones or bile duct dilation on ultrasound. PSC is associated with autoimmune diseases, especially ulcerative colitis.

Option D: ERCP is the gold standard for diagnosing PSC, as it can directly visualize the characteristic beaded appearance of bile ducts caused by strictures and dilations.

ERCP also provides clear images of the intrahepatic ducts in primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) and facilitates stenting and drainage of obstructed, infected segments.

Option A: AMA is associated with PBC, not PSC. There are no specific serologic markers for PSC.

Option B: The CT scan is not sensitive enough to detect the beaded appearance of the bile ducts, which is characteristic of PSC. ERCP or MRI is more useful.

Option C: The HIDA scan evaluates gallbladder function and bile flow, but it does not assess bile duct fibrosis or strictures, which are central to PSC.

Key Take Home Point:

Liver function tests reveal a cholestatic pattern, elevated serum ALP and gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGTP), and smaller rises in the aminotransferases; bilirubin values can be variable.

MRCP (or ERCP) may demonstrate stricturing and beading of the bile ducts. A liver biopsy is helpful to confirm the diagnosis (concentric periductal 'onion skinning') and may help guide therapy by excluding cirrhosis.

PSC can recur after Liver transplantation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with acute weakness and confusion. Serum sodium is 118 mEq/L. What is the next best step in her management?
questions.solution:
OPTION A - Fluid restriction is appropriate for chronic or mild hyponatremia but not for acute severe cases.

OPTION B - Hypertonic saline infusion is the treatment of choice for severe symptomatic hyponatremia to prevent cerebral edema.

OPTION C - Oral salt tablets are used in chronic hyponatremia but are not suitable for acute management.

OPTION D - Normal saline may worsen hyponatremia in patients with SIADH due to increased free water retention.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

  1. Severe symptomatic hyponatremia (e.g., seizures or confusion) warrants cautious correction using 3% hypertonic saline.
  2. Avoid rapid correction to prevent osmotic demyelination syndrome-target an increase of no more than 6-8 mEq/L in 24 hours.
  3. Identify and treat the underlying cause (e.g., SIADH, adrenal insufficiency).

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with an abnormal first trimester ultrasound showing a thickened nuchal translucency and an absence of nasal bone. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The combination of thickened nuchal translucency and absence of the nasal bone on first trimester screening is highly suggestive of Down syndrome (Trisomy 21). This is an important marker in early screening for chromosomal abnormalities.

Optionwise Explanation:

A) Down syndrome (Correct Answer):

  • Down syndrome (Trisomy 21) is the most likely diagnosis given the findings of thickened nuchal translucency and absence of the nasal bone on first trimester ultrasound.
  • These are known markers for Down syndrome, which is a chromosomal abnormality caused by an extra copy of chromosome 21.
  • First trimester screening for Down syndrome typically includes measurements of nuchal translucency, and the absence of the nasal bone, along with other factors like maternal age, serum markers, and fetal anatomy.
  • Other ultrasound findings that may suggest Down syndrome include shortened femur length, echogenic bowel, and heart defects.

B) Turner syndrome:

  • Turner syndrome (45, X) is a chromosomal condition that affects females, characterized by the absence of one X chromosome.
  • The nuchal translucency is often thickened in Turner syndrome, but the absence of the nasal bone is not a specific feature.
  • Turner syndrome is typically diagnosed through karyotyping and often presents with other features like short stature, webbed neck, ovarian dysfunction, and heart defects.

C) Edwards syndrome (Trisomy 18):

  • Edwards syndrome is characterized by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 18.
  • While thickened nuchal translucency can be seen in Edwards syndrome, the absence of the nasal bone is not a typical finding.
  • Other features of Edwards syndrome include severe developmental delays, clenched hands, rocker-bottom feet, and heart defects.

D) Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13):

  • Patau syndrome involves an extra copy of chromosome 13 and is associated with severe intellectual disability and multiple congenital anomalies.
  • The absence of the nasal bone and thickened nuchal translucency can occasionally be seen, but these findings are less specific than in Down syndrome.
  • Other features of Patau syndrome include polydactyly, holoprosencephaly, and cleft lip/palate.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis shown in the post-operative image given below.
questions.solution:
The image shown here is a post-operative image of debridement done for meleney gangrene ( Necrotising soft tissue infection) of the abdominal wall.

KeyTakeAwayPoint:

Necrotizing fasciitis is a rapidly spreading infection that produces necrosis of the subcutaneous tissues and overlying skin. It is caused by β-hemolytic streptococci and, occasionally, Staphylococcus aureus, but may take the form of a polymicrobial infection associated with other aerobic and anaerobic pathogens, including Bacteroides, Clostridium, Proteus, Pseudomonas, and Klebsiella. It is termed Fournier's gangrene when it affects the perineal area and Meleney's gangrene when it involves the abdominal wall.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presents with confusion, vertigo, and dysphagia. MRI reveals a lesion in the territory of the posterior cerebral artery. Which of the following symptoms is most likely to be associated with this stroke?
questions.solution:
OPTION A - Contralateral hemiparesis would be more likely in a stroke involving the anterior cerebral or middle cerebral artery.

OPTION B - Homonymous hemianopia (loss of vision in the same visual field of both eyes) is a classic sign of a stroke in the posterior cerebral artery territory.

OPTION C - Ipsilateral facial droop is more commonly seen in strokes affecting the brainstem or the facial nerve.

OPTION D - Dysphagia without associated weakness is more likely seen in certain brainstem strokes, but homonymous hemianopia is more directly associated with a PCA stroke.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: A stroke involving the posterior cerebral artery can lead to visual disturbances, including homonymous hemianopia, in addition to confusion and vertigo.

choices.text: In gastroschisis, the herniated bowel is enclosed in a membrane.
Gastroschisis is commonly associated with heart defects.
Omphalocele is often linked to chromosomal abnormalities.
A silo bag is used to cover the exposed bowel in the omphalocele.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding defects of the abdominal wall in neonates?
questions.solution:
Option C: Omphalocele is frequently associated with aneuploidies and other genetic syndromes (e.g. Beckwith-Wiedemann).Other structural anomalies that are common (e.g. cardiac malformations)

Option A: In gastroschisis, an abdominal wall defect lies on the right-hand side of the umbilical cord and transmits to the small and large intestine, stomach, bladder, and sometimes the ovaries or undescended abdominal testes.

Option B: Risk factors for Gastroschisis include teenage pregnancy, recreational drugs, smoking, and genitourinary infection in pregnancy.

Option D: Silo bag is used for Gastroschisis

Key take-home message:

questions.text:
A 22-year-old woman presents with fatigue and pallor. She has a history of mild anemia during her childhood and is pregnant at 12 weeks' gestation. Her iron profile shows the following:
Serum iron: 110 μg/dL (Normal: 50-170 μg/dL)
Total iron-binding capacity (TIBC): 330 μg/dL (Normal: 240-450 μg/dL)
Transferrin saturation: 33% (Normal: 20-50%)
Ferritin: 80 ng/mL (Normal: 15-150 ng/mL)
On Hb electrophoresis, HbA2 level was found to be 3.8%.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option-wise explanation:

  • A) Iron deficiency anemia: This would typically show low serum iron, high TIBC, low ferritin, and low transferrin saturation. However, the patient's iron profile is normal, so iron deficiency anemia is unlikely.
  • B) Thalassemia minor: This is the most likely diagnosis. The normal iron profile combined with an elevated HbA2 level suggests thalassemia minor, which is a genetic disorder involving reduced production of one of the hemoglobin chains. Patients often have mild anemia with normal iron studies and may not show symptoms other than fatigue and pallor.
  • C) Anemia of chronic disease: This usually presents with normal or low serum iron, low TIBC, and normal or increased ferritin. The patient's iron studies do not show characteristics of anemia of chronic disease, making it unlikely.
  • D) Vitamin B12 deficiency: Vitamin B12 deficiency typically presents with macrocytic anemia and neurological symptoms. The patient's iron profile and lack of macrocytosis make this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common location for pressure sore development?
questions.solution:
The sacrum (28%-36%) is the most common area in which pressure sores develop, followed by the heel (23%-30%) and the ischium (17%-20%).

KeyTake Away Points:

choices.text: A direct blow to the knee from the lateral side
Sudden deceleration and pivoting on a fixed foot
Hyperextension of the knee during a fall
Repetitive stress from running on uneven surfaces

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common mechanism of injury for an anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tear?
questions.solution:
Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) Injury

Common Mechanism of Injury:

The most frequent cause of an ACL injury occurs when an athlete suddenly decelerates and pivots on a fixed foot, a movement common in sports like soccer, basketball, and skiing. This action generates significant stress on the ACL, often leading to a tear.

While other mechanisms, such as direct trauma or hyperextension, can also cause ACL injuries, pivoting and deceleration remain the most common triggers.

Associated Injuries:

  • The ACL is most commonly ruptured in association with tears of the medial collateral ligament (MCL) or lateral collateral ligament (LCL).
  • Often, ACL injuries are caused by a twisting force applied to a semi-flexed knee.
  • A combination of injuries to the medial collateral ligament (MCL), medial meniscus, and anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) is frequently seen together, a pattern known as the O'Donoghue Triad.

Anterior Drawer Test and Lachmann Test

Anterior Drawer Test:

  • This test is used to detect injury to the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL).
  • It involves pulling the tibia anteriorly while the knee is flexed at 90 degrees, assessing the amount of forward movement or instability in the joint.

Lachmann Test:

  • A similar test to the Anterior Drawer Test, the Lachmann Test is performed with the knee flexed at 10-15 degrees.
  • This test specifically assesses the anterior glide of the tibia, providing a more accurate evaluation of ACL injury, especially in cases where the anterior drawer test may be difficult to perform due to muscle guarding.

Sports injuries

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman underwent an uncomplicated cesarean section under spinal anesthesia. On the second postoperative day, she develops severe shortness of breath, tachycardia, and hypotension. Physical examination reveals bilateral rales in the lungs. What is the most likely cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with severe shortness of breath, tachycardia, hypotension, and bilateral rales in the lungs, which are concerning for pulmonary embolism (PE). Pulmonary embolism is a life-threatening condition that can present with these symptoms, especially after surgery, including cesarean sections. It typically presents with sudden onset of shortness of breath, chest pain, and signs of right heart failure (tachycardia, hypotension, and rales in the lungs).
  • Pulmonary embolism occurs when a clot, often originating from the deep veins of the legs (deep vein thrombosis or DVT), travels to the lungs and blocks the pulmonary arteries. The risk of PE is higher in the postpartum period due to hypercoagulability, immobility, and the increased risk of venous thromboembolism after cesarean section.
  • Postoperative pneumonia (B) could also present with respiratory distress and rales, but it typically develops later than this (usually after 3-5 days). The acute onset and severity in this patient, in addition to the lack of fever or productive cough, make pneumonia less likely.
  • Acute myocardial infarction (C) may present with tachycardia, hypotension, and shortness of breath, but it typically also involves chest pain or discomfort. The bilateral rales in the lungs, which suggest fluid accumulation, are not typically seen in a myocardial infarction.
  • Fat embolism (D) can occur after trauma or orthopedic surgery (especially long bone fractures) and typically presents with a characteristic triad of respiratory distress, neurological changes, and petechial rash. While it is possible in any surgical patient, the presentation in this case, which includes severe shortness of breath and bilateral rales on the second postoperative day, is more consistent with pulmonary embolism.

Given the clinical presentation and the timing of onset after surgery, pulmonary embolism is the most likely diagnosis.

Topic: Caesarean section

Reference: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) Practice Bulletin No. 183: Thrombosis in Pregnancy

questions.text: A previously healthy 20-month-old female is brought to the urgent-care clinic during the evening with a barking cough. On examination her rectal temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), respiratory rate 18/min, heart rate 120 beats/min, and O2 saturation 94%. She has stridor, with mild substernal retractions only when her temperature was taken. Which one of the following would be most appropriate at this point?
questions.solution:
• Croup can be classified as spasmodic croup, laryngotracheitis, laryngotracheobronchitis (LTB), laryngotracheobroncheopneumonia (LTBP), or laryngeal diphtheria.
  • Mild croup is manifested by an occasional barking cough with no stridor at rest, and mild or absent intercostal retractions.
  • Moderate croup presents with a more frequent barking cough, stridor with suprasternal and sternal retractions at rest, but no agitation.
  • Severe croup includes more prominent inspiratory and expiratory stridor with agitation and distress.
  • There is good evidence that corticosteroids produce significant improvement. The regimens studied most frequently have consisted of single-dose dexamethasone (0.6 mg/kg orally or intramuscularly), with some studies including up to four more doses over a 2- day period.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with localized pain and swelling in his thigh, along with fever and weight loss. Imaging shows a diaphyseal lesion with periosteal reaction forming an "onion-skin" appearance. Biopsy confirms the presence of small, round blue cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ewing's Sarcoma

Overview:

  • Age Group: Most common in 10-20 years, can occur up to 30 years.

Pathology:

  • Bones Affected: Commonly in long bones (femur, tibia), also in flat bones (pelvis, calcaneum).
  • Location: Primarily in the diaphysis of long bones.
  • Gross Pathology: Grey-white, soft tumor with expansion and periosteal new bone formation (onion-peel appearance).
  • Histopathology: Small, uniform cells resembling lymphocytes, forming pseudo-rosettes.

Clinical Features:

  • Presents with pain, swelling, and sometimes fever.
  • Often confused with osteomyelitis due to fever.

Examination:

  • Swelling in the diaphysis of long bones, suggestive of a malignant tumor.

Radiological Features:

  • Typical: Lytic lesion in the medullary zone with onion-peel appearance.
  • Atypical: May involve metaphysis, resembling osteomyelitis or soft tissue sarcoma.
  • In flat bones, primarily lytic with little new bone formation.

Bone tumours

questions.text: What is the primary mechanism of action of bisphosphonates in treating postmenopausal osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
Option-wise Explanation

A. Inhibition of osteoblast activity

Bisphosphonates do not inhibit osteoblasts, which are responsible for bone formation. Instead, they primarily target osteoclasts to reduce bone resorption.

B. Inhibition of RANKL expression

While RANKL (Receptor Activator of Nuclear Factor Kappa-B Ligand) plays a role in osteoclast activation, bisphosphonates do not directly inhibit RANKL expression. This mechanism is associated with drugs like denosumab.

C. Inhibition of osteoclast-mediated bone resorption

This is the primary mechanism of bisphosphonates. They bind to hydroxyapatite in bone and are taken up by osteoclasts during bone resorption. This disrupts osteoclast function and induces apoptosis, reducing bone turnover and improving bone density.

D. Stimulation of parathyroid hormone secretion

Bisphosphonates do not stimulate parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion. On the contrary, PTH analogs like teriparatide are used to stimulate bone formation in certain cases of osteoporosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC) presents with tense ascites and no hepatic encephalopathy. Lab results: bilirubin 5 mg/dL, albumin 2.8 g/dL, INR 2.0. Using the Modified CTP score for PSC, calculate the patient's score.
questions.solution:
KeyTakeAwayPoint:

The three most common objective measures of surgical risk in cirrhotic patients are the Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) score, the MELD score, and residual liver volume.

The Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) score was originally developed to evaluate the risk of portocaval shunt procedures performed for portal hypertension and subsequently is useful in predicting surgical risks of other intra-abdominal operations on cirrhotic patients.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman, 5 days postpartum, presents with severe mood swings, irritability, and disturbed sleep. She expresses feelings of hopelessness, and her family reports that she has withdrawn from social interactions. She denies any history of psychiatric illness. On examination, she is tearful and shows significant anxiety.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Postpartum depression (A): This is the most likely diagnosis given the patient's symptoms of severe mood swings, irritability, disturbed sleep, feelings of hopelessness, and social withdrawal. The onset within the first few weeks postpartum is characteristic of postpartum depression, which is often marked by depressive symptoms like sadness, anxiety, and loss of interest, without psychotic features. It affects 10-15% of women after childbirth.
  • Postpartum psychosis (B): Although this condition can present with mood swings and irritability, it is more severe and includes psychotic symptoms such as hallucinations or delusions, which are not present in this case. Postpartum psychosis usually occurs within the first 2 weeks postpartum and requires urgent psychiatric intervention.
  • Adjustment disorder (C): This condition occurs in response to a stressful life event, but it usually does not cause the severity of symptoms seen here, such as significant mood disturbances and hopelessness. Adjustment disorder is typically less severe than postpartum depression and does not usually involve prolonged depressive symptoms.
  • Bipolar disorder (D): Bipolar disorder involves alternating periods of depression and mania. While this patient has depressive symptoms, there is no evidence of a manic or hypomanic episode, which would be required for a diagnosis of bipolar disorder. Furthermore, the onset is related to the postpartum period, making postpartum depression more likely.

Reference: American Psychiatric Association. Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5).

questions.text: Under the NVBDCP, which of the following is the main objective of epidemic preparedness and rapid response?
questions.solution:
• The National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) is implemented in the state/UTs for prevention and control of vector borne diseases namely Malaria, Filariasis, Kala-azar, Japanese Encephalitis, Dengue and Chikungunya.
  • Under NVBDCP, three-pronged strategy for prevention and control of vector borne diseases are :-
  • Disease management including early case detection and complete treatment, strengthening of referral services, epidemic preparedness and rapid response.
  • Integrated vector management for transmission risk reduction including indoor residual spraying in selected high-risk areas, use of insecticide treated bed nets, use of larvivorous fish, anti-larval measures in urban areas, source reduction and minor environmental engineering.
  • Supportive interventions including behaviour change communication (BCC), public private partnership and inter-sectoral convergence, human resource development, operational research, monitoring and evaluation, web-based management information system, vaccination against JE and annual mass drug administration against lymphatic filariasis.

The modified Hinchey classification is widely used to categorize acute colonic diverticulitis (ACD) into four main stages (I-IV) with two subcategories (Ia and Ib), based on disease severity.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman at 7 weeks of gestation presents to the emergency department with heavy bleeding and cramping. Ultrasound reveals a non-viable intrauterine pregnancy with no fetal heart activity. She requests a medical termination of pregnancy. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option for her?
questions.solution:
A) Dilation and curettage (D&C)

  • D&C is a surgical method for terminating pregnancies, but it is typically used for cases of complete miscarriage or retained products of conception, not for early medical termination or missed miscarriage when the patient prefers a non-surgical approach. However, D&C is also an option in cases of heavy bleeding or incomplete abortion, but medical management is preferred for early gestational age.

B) Misoprostol alone

  • Misoprostol is a prostaglandin that induces uterine contractions and is used to expel pregnancy tissue. However, mifepristone followed by misoprostol is the more effective medical regimen, as mifepristone (a progesterone antagonist) enhances the action of misoprostol and is recommended for more reliable outcomes in medical abortion.

C) Methotrexate

  • Methotrexate is typically used in the management of ectopic pregnancy. It inhibits DNA synthesis and is not suitable for intrauterine pregnancies or missed abortions.

D) Mifepristone followed by misoprostol

  • This is the most appropriate option for a missed miscarriage. Mifepristone is administered first to block progesterone, which is necessary for maintaining the pregnancy, and then misoprostol is given to induce uterine contractions and expel the pregnancy. This combination is highly effective and is recommended for medical management of missed abortion in early pregnancy.

Topic: MTP

Reference: ACOG Practice Bulletin No. 143: Medical Management of First-Trimester Abortion (2014)

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect about the "Miami criteria"

Concept: Intraoperative PTH measurements may guide the need to convert from a focused to a cervical exploration.

Option C: A drop in the plasma PTH into the normal range and to less than half the maximum preoperative PTH at 10 minutes appears to accurately predict single-gland disease. Therefore, a significant drop should be detected in the plasma PTH following the resection of a single adenoma. If no such drop is detected, then multi-gland disease may be suspected, and conversion to a bilateral neck exploration should be considered.

Other options:

Option B: The Miami criteria were developed to determine the extent of resection.

Option D: IOPTH monitoring is a commonly used adjunct, which guides the surgeon on when to stop the parathyroid exploration. It helps confirm that there is no residual hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue.

KeyTakeAway Point:

questions.text: Which of the following biochemical markers in amniotic fluid is used to assess fetal lung maturity?
questions.solution:
The L/S ratio is a marker of fetal lung maturity. An L/S ratio ≥2:1 indicates mature fetal lungs.

A) Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is a protein produced by the fetal liver and is primarily used to screen for neural tube defects and certain congenital abnormalities. It is not used to assess fetal lung maturity.

B) Lecithin/Sphingomyelin (L/S) ratio

The Lecithin/Sphingomyelin (L/S) ratio is a key biochemical marker used to assess fetal lung maturity. The ratio of these phospholipids increases as the fetus approaches term, indicating adequate surfactant production in the lungs. An L/S ratio of 2:1 or higher generally indicates fetal lung maturity.

C) Beta-hCG

Beta-hCG is a hormone produced by the placenta and is primarily used to confirm pregnancy and assess for conditions like ectopic pregnancy or gestational trophoblastic disease. It is not used for assessing fetal lung maturity.

D) Estriol

Estriol is a hormone produced by the placenta and the fetal liver, and it can be measured as part of prenatal screening for certain fetal abnormalities. However, estriol is not used to assess fetal lung maturity.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with fatigue, weight gain, constipation, and cold intolerance. On examination, she has a puffy face, brittle nails, and dry skin. Laboratory results show elevated TSH and low free T4. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Primary hypothyroidism is the most likely diagnosis, characterized by elevated TSH and low free T4, along with typical symptoms such as weight gain, constipation, and cold intolerance.
  • Option B: Secondary hypothyroidism would show low TSH as well as low free T4.
  • Option C: Hyperthyroidism presents with symptoms of weight loss, tachycardia, and heat intolerance.
  • Option D: Pheochromocytoma typically presents with episodic hypertension, sweating, and palpitations.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Primary hypothyroidism presents with elevated TSH, low free T4, and symptoms of fatigue, weight gain, and cold intolerance.

choices.text: It is more commonly seen with solid organ transplants than with intestinal transplant

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding PTLD?
questions.solution:
PTLD is a potential complication of immunosuppression for any patient after a transplant.

Option C: If diagnosed with PTLD the first-line treatment is usually with rituximab and immunosuppression reduction. This has to be done with great caution in multivisceral/ intestinal transplant recipients because of the risk of rejection and the consequences thereof.

Option A: The incidence in intestinal transplant recipients is higher than for other solid organ transplant recipients - up to 17% in some series. This is likely to be due to both the level of immunosuppression and the amount of lymphoid tissue associated with an intestinal-containing graft.

Option B: Treatment in severe cases, involves reducing immunosuppression with or without antiviral medications.

Option D: PTLD should be considered if there is a persistent positive EBV viremia or B symptoms such as night sweats, unexplained fevers, and weight loss.

KeytakeAway Point:

Intestinal transplantation is the most challenging area of abdominal transplantation, with higher rates of complications than other transplant groups.

These complications include rejection, sepsis, post-transplant lymphoproliferative disease (PTLD), and graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).

questions.text: There are lot of maternal and child health problems from which the developing countries are affected, currently the main health problems affecting the health of the mother and child in India revolve round the triad of?
questions.solution:
• Currently, the main health problems affecting the health of the mother and the child in India, as in other developing countries revolve round the triad of malnutrition, infection, and the consequences of unregulated fertility.
  • Malnutrition: - Malnutrition is like an iceberg, most people in the developing countries live under the burden of malnutrition. The adverse effects of maternal malnutrition have been well documented - maternal depletion, low birth weight, anaemia, toxemias of pregnancy, postpartum haemorrhage. Intrauterine life is very important period from nutrition standpoint. The next critical period of childhood is the period of weaning. Nutrition protection and promotion is therefore an essential activity of MCH care.
  • Infection: - Maternal infections may cause a variety of adverse effects such as foetal growth retardation, low birth weight, embryopathy, abortion and puerperal sepsis. As far as the baby is concerned infection may begin with labour and delivery and increase as the child grows older. Children may be ill with debilitating diarrhoeal, respiratory and skin infections for as much as a third of their first year of life.
  • Uncontrolled reproduction: - The Health Hazards for the mother and the child resulting from unregulated fertility have been well recognised- increased prevalence of low birth weight, severe anaemia, abortion, antepartum haemorrhage and a high maternal and perinatal mortality which have shown a sharp rise after the 4th pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is characteristic of subacute meningitis caused by tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Chronic meningitis due to tuberculosis typically has a slow, insidious onset, not rapid.
  • Option B: Tubercular meningitis often shows a lymphocytic predominance, not neutrophils.
  • Option C: The hallmark of tubercular meningitis is granulomatous inflammation.
  • Option D: CSF analysis is typically abnormal in tubercular meningitis, showing elevated protein, low glucose, and a lymphocytic predominance.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Tubercular meningitis presents insidiously with a granulomatous inflammation on biopsy. The combination of unrelenting headache, stiff neck, fatigue, night sweats, and fever with a CSF lymphocytic pleocytosis and a mildly decreased glucose concentration is highly suspicious for tuberculous meningitis.

questions.text: What are the four principles on primary health care?
questions.solution:
• There are four principles of primary health care, they are: -
    • Equitable distribution: - the first key principle in primary health care is equity or equitable distribution of health services that is health services must be equally shared by all people irrespective of their ability to pay, and all must have access to health services.
    • Community participation: - there must be a continuing effort to secure meaningful involvement of the community in the planning, implementation and maintenance of health services, besides maximum reliance on local resources such as manpower, money and materials.
    • Intersectoral coordination: - primary health care involves in addition to the health sector, all related sectors and aspects of national and community development, in particular agriculture, animal husbandry, food industry, education, housing, public works, communication and other sectors.
    • Appropriate technology: - it has been defined as technology that is scientifically sound, adaptable to local needs, and acceptable to those who apply it and those for whom it is used, and that can be maintained by the people themselves in keeping with the principle of self-reliance with the resources the community and country can afford.

questions.text: In the diagnosis of aortic dissection, which of the following is the most important diagnostic tool?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Chest X-ray can show signs of aortic enlargement or widening of the mediastinum but is not definitive for diagnosis.
  • Option B: A CT scan with contrast is the gold standard for diagnosing aortic dissection due to its ability to clearly visualize the aorta and any tears.
  • Option C: ECG may help rule out other conditions like myocardial infarction but is not diagnostic for aortic dissection.
  • Option D: While echocardiography can be helpful in certain cases, it is not as definitive as CT in diagnosing aortic dissection.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: CT with contrast is crucial for confirming the diagnosis of aortic dissection.

questions.text: The quality control of drug sector in India is regulated by?
questions.solution:
• The quality control of the drugs marketed in the country is regulated under the drugs and cosmetics act, 1940 and the drugs and cosmetics rules, 1945.
  • The central drugs standard control organisation (CDSCO), in the directorate of director general of health services, along with drug control organisation in the states are responsible for safety, efficacy and quality of drugs, their import, manufacture, distribution, sale and standards.
  • The main functions of CDSCO include control of the quality of drugs imported into the country, coordination of the activities of the states/UTs Drug control authorities, approval of new drugs proposed to be imported or manufactured in the country, laying down standards and regulatory measures and acting as the central license approving authority.
  • The CDSCO has a network of six zonal offices, six sub-zonal offices and 16 port offices responsible for ensuring quality of imports and 7 laboratories.

questions.text: Which of the following is the characteristic presentation of primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease)?

  • Option C: Hyperglycemia and hypercalcemia are not characteristic of Addison's disease.
  • Option D: Weight loss and decreased appetite are more common in Addison's disease, not increased appetite.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Hyperkalemia, hyponatremia, and hypotension are hallmark signs of primary adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: Which diagnostic test is most specific for hepatic encephalopathy?
questions.solution:
OPTION A - While elevated serum ammonia levels are common, they are not specific to hepatic encephalopathy.

OPTION B - CT scan is used to rule out structural causes of altered mentation but does not confirm hepatic encephalopathy.

OPTION C - EEG can show generalized slowing but is not specific.

OPTION D - The diagnosis of hepatic encephalopathy is clinical. Clinical assessment, based on history, mental status, and precipitating factors, remains the cornerstone of diagnosis.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

  • Portosystemic encephalopathy is a serious complication of chronic liver disease and is broadly defined as an alteration in mental status and cognitive function occurring in the presence of liver failure
  • Hepatic encephalopathy is precipitated by factors like GI bleeding, infection, or medication non-compliance.
  • Treatment focuses on correcting precipitating factors and reducing ammonia levels (e.g., lactulose and rifaximin).

questions.solution:
• Option A: Dengue fever typically presents with high fever, retroorbital pain, and a rash, but not with the characteristic distribution of rash seen here.
  • Option B: Rickettsial infections, such as Rocky Mountain spotted fever, present with a rash that begins on the wrists and ankles and spreads to the palms and soles, along with thrombocytopenia and hyponatremia.
  • Option C: Zika virus infection is typically characterized by fever, rash, and joint pain, but not the distribution of rash seen in this patient.
  • Option D: Malaria presents with cyclical fevers and is unlikely to present with the rash and findings seen here.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Rickettsial infections present with a rash that begins on the wrists and ankles and spreads to the palms and soles.

questions.text: Which of the following is the hallmark clinical feature of Takayasu's arteritis?
questions.solution:
OPTION A - Petechiae are not a feature of Takayasu's arteritis.

OPTION B - Asymmetric blood pressure in the upper limbs due to subclavian artery stenosis is a hallmark feature.

OPTION C - Non-pitting edema is unrelated to Takayasu's arteritis.

OPTION D - Digital gangrene is rare but may occur in severe ischemia.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

  • Takayasu's arteritis primarily affects large arteries, especially the aorta and its major branches.
  • Diagnosis involves imaging modalities like CT or MR angiography.

questions.text: At what gestational age is anti-D immunoglobulin typically administered to Rh-negative women in the absence of fetal-maternal hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
RhD immunoglobulin (Rh immunoglobulin or anti-D) is given to Rh-negative pregnant women to prevent Rh sensitization, which could lead to hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN) in subsequent pregnancies. This process is essential in preventing alloimmunization, a condition where the immune system of the Rh-negative mother forms antibodies against Rh-positive fetal blood cells.

Key Concepts Regarding RAADP (Routine Antenatal Anti-D Prophylaxis):

  1. Indications for RAADP:
    • Routine prophylaxis:
      • For all Rh-negative women at 28 weeks of pregnancy, regardless of whether there is any indication of fetal-maternal hemorrhage.
      • This is administered to prevent Rh sensitization from any potential hidden fetal-maternal bleed.
    • Postpartum prophylaxis:
      • Administered within 72 hours after delivery if the newborn is Rh-positive, to prevent maternal sensitization for future pregnancies.
    • Following events that may cause fetal-maternal hemorrhage:
      • Miscarriage or abortion (any gestational age)
      • Ectopic pregnancy
      • Amniocentesis or chorionic villus sampling (CVS)
      • Abdominal trauma or significant vaginal bleeding
      • External cephalic version (for breech presentation)
  2. Dosage:
    • Routine prophylaxis at 28 weeks: A standard dose of 300 mcg of Rh immunoglobulin is given intramuscularly.
    • Postpartum dose: Another dose of 300 mcg is administered within 72 hours if the newborn is Rh-positive.
  3. Mechanism of Action:
    • The Rh immunoglobulin works by binding to Rh-positive fetal red blood cells in the maternal circulation, preventing the maternal immune system from recognizing and forming antibodies against Rh-positive cells.
  4. Impact:
    • Prevents alloimmunization: If a Rh-negative mother is not sensitized, her immune system does not recognize Rh-positive cells as foreign, preventing the development of antibodies that could harm future pregnancies.
  5. Maternal Sensitization:
    • Sensitization occurs when an Rh-negative woman carries an Rh-positive fetus, and fetal blood cells enter the maternal circulation, prompting the immune system to produce antibodies against the Rh antigen. This is most commonly an issue in subsequent pregnancies, where the antibodies can cross the placenta and attack the fetal red blood cells, causing hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN), which can be severe.
  6. Administration Timing and Effectiveness:
    • Before 28 weeks: If fetal-maternal hemorrhage is suspected (e.g., bleeding, trauma), a dose of Rh immunoglobulin is administered immediately.
    • After 28 weeks (routine dose): This is done as a preventive measure, as small amounts of fetal blood may enter the maternal circulation without being noticed.
    • Postpartum (if the baby is Rh-positive): Given within 72 hours to prevent sensitization from any remaining fetal blood cells that might enter the maternal circulation during delivery.
  7. Efficacy:
    • When administered correctly and in the recommended timing, RAADP is highly effective in preventing Rh sensitization, with greater than 99% success in preventing hemolytic disease in subsequent pregnancies.

Clinical Guidelines:

  • Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists (RCOG): Recommends routine administration at 28 weeks and postpartum (within 72 hours) if the baby is Rh-positive.
  • American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG): Recommends similar guidelines, emphasizing the 28-week prophylaxis for Rh-negative women and the postpartum dose.

Topic: Anti D administration

Reference: Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists (RCOG) Green-top Guideline No. 56: "Prevention of RhD Alloimmunisation"

questions.text: In an eFAST examination, which of the following ultrasound probe configurations is most appropriate for balancing penetration depth and image resolution to assess both thoracic and abdominal trauma effectively?
questions.solution: Medical ultrasound uses frequencies in the range of 3-20 MHz. The higher the frequency of the ultrasound wave, the greater the resolution of the image, but the less depth of view from the skin. Consequently, abdominal imaging uses transducers with a frequency of 3-7 MHz, while higher frequency transducers are used for superficial structures, such as musculoskeletal and breast ultrasound.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with vaginal discharge that is thin, grayish-white, and has a fishy odor. A wet mount reveals clue cells, and a vaginal pH test is positive (greater than 4.5). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• A) Candidiasis: Typically presents with thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge. Vaginal pH in candidiasis is typically less than 4.5, and there is usually no fishy odor. The clue cells seen on wet mount are absent in candidiasis.
  • B) Trichomoniasis: Trichomoniasis causes yellow-green, frothy discharge, often with a frothy consistency and a fishy odor. However, it is usually associated with vulvar itching, erythema, and cervical petechiae (strawberry cervix), which are not seen in this patient.
  • C) Bacterial vaginosis: The classic presentation of bacterial vaginosis includes thin, grayish-white discharge, a fishy odor, and a positive vaginal pH (greater than 4.5). Wet mount showing clue cells is highly suggestive of this diagnosis. The condition is caused by an overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria and a depletion of lactobacilli.
  • D) Chlamydia infection: Chlamydia typically causes cervicitis and may present with discharge, but it is not associated with clue cells or a positive vaginal pH. Chlamydia is often asymptomatic, and the discharge is usually not described as having a fishy odor.

Topic: Bacterial vaginosis

questions.text: The HabrGama protocol is followed in which of the following cancers?
questions.solution:
Approximately 20% of rectal cancers treated by neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy show a complete clinical response with no evidence of residual cancer on clinical examination, biopsy, or radiological imaging.

There is an increasing trend for such patients to be offered the option of 'watch and wait' (HabrGama) in the hope that they may have been cured of the disease and spared the morbidity of resectional surgery. Some 30% of cases will recur on a 'watch and wait' policy, but surgical resection can salvage most.

KeyTake Away Point:

HabrGama protocol is followed in rectal cancers.

Tags:

  • Topic: Colorectal cancer; Cancers
  • PYQ: NEET 2023

questions.text: A 57-year old woman presents with postmenopausal bleeding. She has a BMI of 35 and a family history of endometrial cancer. Pelvic ultrasound shows a thickened endometrium of 15 mm. Endometrial biopsy confirms endometrial carcinoma. What is the most likely subtype of endometrial carcinoma in this patient?
questions.solution:
OPTION A: Endometrioid carcinoma is the most common subtype of endometrial carcinoma, especially in postmenopausal women. It is strongly associated with unopposed estrogen exposure, obesity (high BMI), and metabolic syndrome. This patient's thickened endometrium and obesity fit this profile.

OPTION B: Serous carcinoma is a more aggressive subtype associated with atrophic endometrium rather than hyperplasia. It is less common and typically presents in older women, often without a history of obesity or estrogen excess.

OPTION C: Clear cell carcinoma is a rare and aggressive subtype of endometrial carcinoma, accounting for <5% of cases.

OPTION D: Mixed Müllerian tumor (carcinosarcoma) is also a rare, aggressive tumor that contains both epithelial and mesenchymal components, more likely seen in older women but less associated with obesity and estrogen stimulation.

Topic: Endometrial cancer

Reference: ACOG Practice Bulletin No. 149: Endometrial Cancer

questions.text: What is the primary treatment approach for a Monteggia fracture-dislocation in adults?
questions.solution:
Monteggia Fracture-Dislocation

Definition: Monteggia fracture-dislocation involves a fracture of the upper third of the ulna with dislocation of the radial head.

Causes:

  1. Indirect Injury: Most commonly caused by a fall on an outstretched hand.
  2. Direct Trauma: Can also occur due to a direct blow to the back of the upper forearm.

Types: The injury is classified based on the angulation of the ulna fracture:

  1. Extension Type (Most Common):
    • The ulna fracture angulates anteriorly (extends), and the radial head dislocates anteriorly.
  2. Flexion Type:
    • The ulna fracture angulates posteriorly (flexes), and the radial head dislocates posteriorly.

Diagnosis:

  • In cases of an isolated fracture of the upper half of the ulna, careful examination for dislocation of the radial head is essential (Fig. 15.3).
  • Missed diagnosis can lead to complications and deformities.

Treatment:

  • Monteggia fractures are highly unstable injuries that frequently redisplace even after an initial reduction.
  • Definitive Treatment:
    • Open Reduction and Internal Fixation (ORIF):
    • A plate is used to stabilize the ulna fracture.
    • Reduction of the ulna fracture usually leads to the automatic realignment of the radial head.

Complications:

  1. Malunion:
    • Commonly occurs when the injury is treated conservatively and redisplacement within the plaster is undetected.
    • Results in deformity of the forearm and restriction of elbow and forearm movements.
  2. PIN palsy: Posterior interossious nerve frequently gets stretched in monteggia fracture dislocations either due to the displaced fracture or during surgical intervention.

Topic: Upper limb trauma
